div.p: THE LIFE and LIGHT of a man IN CHRIST.

q.p: But covet earnestly the best gifts, and yet shew I unto you a more excellent way. 1. Cor. 12.13.
Prove all things, hold fast that which is good. 1. Thes. 5.21.
And I bretheren, when I came to you, came not with excellency of speech, or of wisdome, declaring unto you the testimony of God.
For I determined not to know any thing among you, save Iesus Christ, and him crucified.

div.q: Who shall not feare the O Lord, and glorify thy name? For thou onely art holy. Rev. 15.4.
div.p: LONDON Printed by Thomas. Pain, MD.C.X.L.V.I.

div.head: The Preface.
div.p:
DEare child of God, whose soul & body is consecrated & united, unto the true light & love of Christ thy eternall wel-being, who saves the from thy sins. Having had some sad & serious thoughts of the present condition of all sorts of People, but especially of those of the three Kingdomes, concerning true Religion, which should be built upon truth. And finding, to the sorrow of my soul (notwithstanding my most charitable thoughts) the dolefull discent of the Religion now professed, from truth, I was like unto a troubled and astonished man, who seeth his dearely beloved friend lying upon the deep water, in great danger to be drowned, and can make him no reliefe,
otherwise, then by abrupt thoughts and wishings. Charity did bid me looke upon the divided Churches of Gods people, as people following their light; truth did bid me looke upon the most part of them; as buyers and sellers in their Temple Religions. Thus was me Soul conflicted, betwixt charity in it's largest extent, and divine truth in it's pure simplicity: But Truth at last overcame my unsoundly grounded charity, as the Sun doth the darke Myst, and b • came an Ambassadour, sent unto me by the King of Love, that I shoul • as a faithfull Servant, and lover of truth, not mind my own things, but the things that might do good to my dearly beloved indangered friends, the Lords People, preferring the good of my br •
ther, before mine own. Whereupon divine communicative love, like unto new Wine, began to seek a vent in my spirit, and commanded me to write this little Treatise, for thy sake, and f •
••
thy good, as also for the good of any of Gods creatures in these times of contention amongst people, concerning the way of Truth. And here again I had a great conflict, for there did arise a three-fold opposition to diswade me. The first, was a conscientiou • nesse of my in-abillity, which Moses-like did plead Stammering lips. The second was l • st any one of the divided Congregations should conceive me to be a rayler again them. The third was, that this little treatise, should either not be understood or else be branded with the aspersion of error, in regard, that the most part of men, and Proffessors in these times, & especially the persons who out-strip the rest in knowledge, (as they call it) are so in naturalized, and baptized, in the principles of their own understandings, that the true light is little otherwise esteemed of by them, then false light is esteemed of by a Child of true light; which three difficulties, although they
did strive each one more then another to disswade the casting in of this widows mite, into the treasury of this Generation: Yet divine authority did silence their pleading, and convinced their reasons, saying to the first, It is not yee that speake, but the Spirit of your heavenly father speaketh in you, Math. 10.20. To the second, But with me it is a very smal thing, that J should be judged of mans judgement, 1. Cor. 4.3. To the third, my sheep heare my voice Ioh. 10.27. Thus (deare Reader) am I encouraged and set on worke, to present unto thy view, this little treatise, intituled the Life and Light of a man in Christ; Jf thou be one of those who affect curiosity of speech, rather then the truths of Jesus, it may be, that in stead of being bettered by it, thou mayest be the worse by mocking it, and so it will become a stumbling blocke to the, for it commeth to the, not with excellency of speech, or
intising words of mans wisdome, &c, 1. Cor. 2.1, 4. If thou be one of those who without just ground, doest brand truth with error, and so exclaim and chaffe against it, take heed that thy exclaiming and chaffing, be not against it, but against the Lord, as Moses said to the People, If thou be one of those, who art sensibly sitting in the region and shadow of death & darknesse, and panting after the light, make use of this little Treatise, as a love token sent unto the, from the Father of Lights, who himselfe will lead the out of the darke pits of the worlds darknes, in due time. But if thou be one of those who through Christ art one with God, this litle Treatise can adde nothing to thy good, [supream good I mean] for thou hast that supream good, or rather that supream Good hath the, which this little Treatise testifyeth of.

closer.signed: Thine in the obedience of truth and love.

div.head: CHAP. I. That a man in Christ, doth not adde unto, nor diminish from, the pure word of God.
div.p:
IT is true, and cannot be denyed, but that those who by all meanes do labour, to have & keep the divine Scriptures, pure and simple, from humane addition, or detraction, are in that particular nearer the truth, then those who do adde unto, and diminish from the same: But it is no lesse true, and no lesse to be denyed, that many who do earnestly vindicate the written word of God, from addition, or detraction, of the meer inventions
of men, do grievously, and grosly, both adde unto, and detract from the All-truth working Will and Spirit of the God of Scripture, and of all things else; the which thing, that it may evidently appeare, and be made good upon abso • ute g • ounds of truth, and not out of a bitter and rayling humour [which in the sight and judgement of the God of mercy, meeknes and Love, is no lesse evill in the Rayler, then in the deservedly rayled upon] I shall entreat in the Bowels of Love, all you whosoever that read this Treatise, that you would as the Disciples of Christ, without disparagement of you Reformation, personall righteousnesse, and knowledge as you call it, looke upon, and learn at a man in Christ, how he doth not adde unto, nor diminish from the pure word of the Lord, comparatively with your not adding unto, nor diminishing
from the same, and although the truth of Christ, beareth an absolute authority, and invincible proofe to & in it selfe, although it be barely spoken; yet seing your manner is to affect prooffs of Scripture, for what some men speak, and write, [and it were very well done, if yee could rellish nothing but approved truth] I shall endeavour in the vertue of Christ, to build upon no other foundation, except these two, namely, the divine life of Christ in the holy Scriptures, and the divine word of Christ in the same, in holding out the life of a man in Christ, in this point: As also
• is life in the points following.

A man in Christ, is no further a man in Christ, then Christ is, and lives in him, as Christ is, and lives in him, he is and lives in Christ. Even so the body is no further a living body, th • n the living soul is and liveth
in the body; as the living soul is, and liveth in the body, the body is active and liveth in the soul; this divine truth, did the truth it selfe, the Lord Christ teach his Disciples, when he said, Abide in me, and I in you; as the branch cannot beare fruit of it selfe except it abide in the Vine, no more can yee, except ye abide in me. Ioh. 15.4. So that a man in Christ, is no other thing, but a mysticall subject or body passive, in which the holy Spirit of God and Christ, in an operative manifestation, fulfilleth all righteousnes, leadeth into all truth, subjecteth the subject in which it acteth to it selfe, whose fruits and effects is most sweetly set forth in the 1. Cor. 13. now this, almighty and divine spirit living in a man in Christ, is no way contradictory to it selfe, in adding to, or detracting from, its own pure word; either externall or internall, the externall is
the written word, which the holy men of God spake as they were moved by the holy Ghost, 2. Pet. 1.21. the internall, is the spirit & life of the externall, & of all things else which have spirit and life; according to the divine truth of that Scripture, For of him, and to him, and through him are all things, to whom be glory forever, Amen. Rom. 11.5. the end of the externall word, is the operative will of the internall word manifesting it self into action, unto which the externall word, is a testimony, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Search the Scriptures for in them ye think ye have eternall life, and they are they that t • stfy o me. Ioh 5, 39. The will, mind, and end of the internall operative spirit, and life, is to be a living active Lord God, in a dead passive creatu • e; according to the divine truth of these Scriptures, I live, yet not I, but Christ
liveth in me; and the life which I now live in the flesh, I live by the faith of the son of God. Gal. 2.20. And again, For you are dead, and your life is hid with Christ in God. Col. 3.3. This now [the Lord to be a living active God, in a dead passive creature] is the very substance of Law and Gospell; according to the divine truth of that Scripture, For what the Law could not do, in that it was weake through the fl • sh, God sending his own son, in the likenesse of sinfull flesh, and for sin condemned sin in the flesh, that the righteousnes of the law might be fulfilled in us; who walk not after the flesh, but after the spirit. Rom. 8.3, 4. This as Solomon saith, is, the conclusion of the whole matter? Feare God and keep his commandements: for this is the whole duty of man. Ecles. 12.13. which place is expounded according to God and truth in Phil. 2.13. thus, worke out your own salvation
with feare and trembling; for it is God which worketh in you both to will, and to doe, of his good pleasure, this as Christ the truth it selfe saith, is eternall life; because it is the only true knowledge of the onely true God, & Iesus Christ whom he hath sent, and this is that pure word of God, unto which, and from which a man in Christ, as he is in Christ, doth neither adde unto, nor diminish from; therefore in so far as creature man will be more then a dead passive creature, in so far he addeth to the pure word of God: and in so far as by evill and sin, he b • ing but a finite creature, liveth, and acteth in himselfe, himselfe not being his own creature, but Gods creature, in so farre he diminisheth from the pure word of God. Let every one that readeth this little Book, bring them selves to a true impartial triall here, and if they do, they will find themselves
at a farther distance, from the true life of a man in Christ, touching this point, then they were aware of, yea they will heare the holy spirit of God, and their own consciences uttering such speeches with in themselves, against themselves, as they would tearme madnes, bitternes and error, being uttered by the mouth of man unto them.

div.head: CHAP. II. That a man in Christ doth not approve of sinne.
div.p:
AS the Sun cannot send forth darknes, but light, so the Sun of righteousnes and purity in a man in Christ cannot send forth, or approve of sin, but purity and holines; for sin is both contrary to purity & holines, and is the want of purity & holines. Notwithstanding, as it is possible, that sometimes clouds may inte • ve • n betwixt a man who delighteth
to be in the Sun-shine, and the Sun: so it is possible, that sometime, yea frequently, yea ordinarily, the Serpent, and will of man, may insinuate it selfe, betwixt the soul of a man in Christ, and Christ, and say, yea, hath God said thou shalt be a dead passive creature and he a living acting God? Doe thou the contrary, be thou a living active creature, for in so doing thou shalt be as God; here now is a battle betwixt Michael and the Dragon, betwixt David and Goliah, betwixt the seed of the Woman and the seed of the SERPENT, betwixt the spirit of Christ and the Devill.
And this is that onely sin, and nothing else, which is sin in the judgment of a man in Christ.

And in this point, a man in Christ doth much differ from many who do confesse sin, and who professe hatred against it: for he is like unto
a chast wife, who for the true love she beares unto her own true husband, would tremble at the very thoughts of lying with a Whore
• aster; which act her soul abhor
• eth: But those that are not men in Christ, are like unto a lustfull deluded woman, who runneth away with another womans Husband, and entereth into a false matrimony with him; and notwithstanding that God and her own conscience doth tell her she liveth in sin; yet through the lust of the flesh, and conceit of mariage, she prostituteth her body to the man, and liveth in whoredome; but if it shall come to passe, that shee fall into whoredome with another man, besides this her falsly conceived husband: then she takes on heavily, and is much convinced; but she liveth in whoredome, although she should not play he whore with others besides this
man; because he is not her true but the false husband. and although she conceive a greater evill, in her playing the whore with another then with this man, yet the evill is no lesse, in playing the whore with this man, then with another.

Even so, those that are not with a man in Christ, baptized into a living active God, and a dead passive creatures, but will live and act in, and think that they have warrant and liberty so to do; they are like unto this adulterous woman, often times convinced about this, & that predominant sin (as they call it) when as this predominant sinne of theirs, is nothing so grievous unto them, and in their eyes, as their not being baptized into a living active God, and a dead passive creature, is grievous unto, and in the eyes of God and truth; For it is the very fountain and spring, of all their predominants:
according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Plead with your mother, plead, for she is not my wife, neither am I her husband, let her therefore put away her whoredoms • ut of her sight, and her adulteries from between her breasts. Hosea 2.2.

div.head: CHAP. III. That a man in Christ doth pray • nd read in the Scriptures.
div.p:
THERE is nothing which doeth more move, and unite the affection of a Benefactor • o the party unto which he is beneficiall. then the reall, submissive acknowledgment, and hearty sence of benificiency in the party; and his certainly is a figurative spark • e • f that im-mense and infinite love-justice of the King and Lord of love, shining into, & amongst some men; And there is nothing which is more just and right, then that a
person who lives by the benificiency of a benefactor, should in all reall submissive acknowledgement, & hearty sence, be affected with the love of the benefactor, & this certainly is also a figurative sparkle of that same immense & infinite Love Justice of the God of Love, reflecting and manifesting it self to it self, operatively in & among some men.

Even so there is nothing, which doth more delight, and unite the God of infinite goodnes, & eternall love, to a person who through grace becomes an object of his goodnes, & love, then the reall submissive acknowledgement, and hearty sence of his infinite goodnes, and eternall love, in this object, or rather subject person.

And there is nothing which is more just and right, then that this subject person, who lives by the infinite goodnes and eternall love of
his infinitely good, and eternally loving God, should in all reall submissive acknowledgment, & hearty sence, be affected with, and united unto, this infinite goodnes and eternall love.

For this manifesteth God, to be God, and the creature to be the creature; God to be infinite goodnes, and eternall love, flowing out of himselfe into this submissive sencible, subject person, as into a tem
• le of the holy Ghost and house of prayer; and flowing again into himselfe out of it, the creature to be only the temple & house, & to be unto God as a house is to a man, that is, God active, & the creature passive.

This is the true praise which glorif •• th God; according to the divine truth of that Scripture; Who so o • fereth prayse glorifieth me, and to him that ordereth his conversation aright, will I shew the salvation of the Lord. Psal. 50.23.

Thus the Lord obtaineth his own, so that the Crea • ure can give him nothing which is not his own, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Now therefore our God wee thanke the, & praise thy glorious name, But who am I, and what is my people, that wee should be able to offer so willingly after this sort, for all things come of thee, and of thine own have we given thee, 1. Chron. 29.13.14.

A man in Christ, being baptized into this estate and condition, doth pray, read, &c. and whatsoever he asketh, it is done to him, yea, in him, because he asketh this way truly in the name of Christ? according to the divine truth of that Scripture, And whatsoever yee shall aske in my name, that will I doe, that the Father may be gloryfied in the son, if ye shall aske any thing in my name, I will do it. Ioh. 14.13, 14. there is divine reason for this, for a man i •
Christ, doeth will, and seeke, neither more or lesse, then that which the father in the son, willeth and seeketh in him; the same is to be said, concerning his reading of the Scriptures, & all his godly desires.

Thus doth a man in Christ seek, and he findeth, he knocketh, and it is opened unto him; he asketh and receiveth. But those, (and oh and alas, the most part of men) who are not baptized into the baptisme of a man in Christ, aske and receive not, bēcause they aske a misse. Iam. 4.3. They are like unto hunting Esau, mourning for the blessing, & Simon Magus that would buy Christ, but a man in Christ hath with Mary chosen that good part, which shall not be taken away from him. Luke 10.42.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. That a man in Christ doth heare the Gospell preached.
div.p: AN honest person, having such a disease, as tendeth to the destruction of ease and life in pain and weaknes, so that (as he is moved by God) he would use some meanes, for mitigation of pain, and prolonging of life, according to the will of God, and not according to the will of man.

If this person go out at all to any man of skill, it is certain that it is better to go to such a man, who hath skill in God, then to such as have not their skill in God; now in his thus going our, two things are remark • able, first he hath a reall busines which moves him to go, secondly, he goeth to one, in and by whome the cause & remedy of his disease is truly discovered.

Even so it is with a man in Christ in hearing first he hath a busines of God in his spirit, concerning which he is a captive of God, and panteth after the discovery of it, as the sick person, after the discovery of the cause & remedy of his disease, and even as a fit of sicknes many times doth purge the body, and preventeth a greater sicknesse, yea death it selfe, even so a holy trouble of the mind, being as it were in an eclipse, maketh thee soule of a man in Christ, the more enamour'd with, and united unto the true eternall light, and in a divine good spirituall plight after-wards.

And even as a sick man discerneth the skill of a man, as the man speaketh the very same things, which he knoweth and feeleth in himselfe, or otherwise; even so, a man in Christ, discerneth a true Preacher, that is a true disciple of
Christ, by his own experience; thus doth a man in Christ hēare, not superficially, but as a sick man heareth a true Physitian, discover the cause, and remedy of his disease, i • a divine manner. And as a true Ph •
sitian, getteth his skill by the tru • knowledge of diseases, in applying such & such physick unto such and such diseases: Even so a man in Christ being an instrumental spirituall physitian, in the hand of the eternall Physitian, getteth his skill, by the working of God in the soul of his brother; being a man in Christ, aswell as by the working of God in his own soul; And in this divine sence, a man in Christ, although he be a hearer, may upon conference, be a Physian to a man in Christ, although he be a Preacher according to the divine truth of that Scripture, For I long to see you, that J may impart unto you some spirituall gift, to
the end you may be established; that is that I may be comforted together with you, by the mutuall faith both of you and me. Rom. 1.11, 12.

But it is otherwise amongst hearers, who are not men in Christ, those that are not in Christ, doe go out to the creatures, without the busines we spake of. Some in stead of this busines, go out because it is Sunday, Sabath, or first day, to heare such a rare Divine, such a knowing People, preach and discourse, to participate of such and such Ordinances, &c. Some to be heard and seen and applauded amongst others, how sweetly and soundly they can tosse a point, what great insight they have in the word, some to shew their goodly apparrell, some to make choise of some Godly man (as they call him) for their husband: Some of a woman to be their wife. But and if these Persons were truly baptized in the baptisme
& religion of a man in Christ namly, God to be a living active God, in a dead passive ceature, that is, not to move, but as they should be moved by God: they would abhorre themselves in dust and ashes, and be convinced by the divine truth of these Scriptures, Son of man these men have set up their Idols in their hearts, & put the stumbling-block of their iniquity before their faces, should I be inquired of at all by them? read Ezek. 14.3.4.5.6.7.8.

And again, But unto the wicked, God saith, what hast thou to doe to declare my Statutes: or that thou shouldest take my covenant into thy mouth, Psal. 50. from 16. to 22. And again, This people draw nigh unto me with their mouth, and honoureth me with their lips, but their hearts are far from me, Mat. 15.7.8. And again, Ye adulterers &c. read Jam. 4.4.

Let those who think that those
Sciptures doth nothing at all concern them, take heed lest the God of truth say to them, as Nathan said to David, thou art the man; Sam. 12.17.

div.head: CHAP V. That a man in Christ, doth sometime speak to his neighbour.
div.p:
IF a tender and loving father, who cheerfully and diligently imployeth his strength and calling, for the sustentation and life of his young children, were demanded, why he should do so, seeing that the young children brought no gaines to him, nor profit, he would answer, that fatherly free love moved and constrained him so to doe; even because the weake young children, could neither bring profit nor gaines to him nor to themselves; and that God and nature required of him so to do, & in so answering, he would speak the very
truth. Likewise if he were demanded whether or not it were sufficient enough for him, that he should go abroad, and look upon food and rayment, and then return to his hungry and naked children, and tell them of such good food & raiment as he had seen, & so satisfy their hunger, and cloath their nakednes with the bare rehearsing of such things, or present painted food, and painted raiment, to satisfy their hunger, and cloath their nakednes.

He would answer, that there were nothing more rediculous then that question, seeing that his children would be nothing better, although he should let them see food and raiment, belonging unto other People without proper use of that food, & that raiment to themselves: much lesse, by the bare telling and speaking of food and raiment which he saw abroad, unto them, or shewing
the painted formes of food and raiment unto them, which could do them no good.

He would say, that no lesse would satisfy his children, then the reall use of reall food and raiment, such as God made to be for his own preservation of his life, & in his so answering he would likewise speake the very truth.

Now in the speaking of a man in Christ to any person, the spirit of the heavenly father, keepeth this same fatherly nature, so that a man in Christ speaketh to the edyfying of any person, who is desirous to heare him, capable in some measure out of meer free love, because the love of Christ constraineth him, nor can he do otherwise; for the Fire must of necessity send forth heat, to those who sit neare it, and the Candle shine, to those who are where it shineth, according to the divine
truth of that Scripture, Let your light so shine before men, that they seeing your good workes may glorify your father which is in Heaven; Mat. 5.16.

This in dwelling word of life & love, in a man in Christ is freely received therefore he freely giveth it, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Freely you have received, freely give; Math. 10.8.

A man in Christ, thinketh it to be a sweet reward, with which he is fully content to be a dead instrument in & by which the God of life motion, action, and eternall love: exerciseth pure and meer goodnes towards any of his creatures.

This is the reward, which the sun in shining the aire in moistning, the water in watering, and the earth in production, have, and desire to have no other reward; the same is to be said of the whole university of nature, set man, as man aside.

And so speaketh & doeth a man in Christ to his neighbour, that is any tractable person, without exception; but those who are not baptised into a living active God, and dead passive creature, with a man in Christ, and yet will take upon them to be leaders of the blind, are those unto whom God and truth, intending their good, directeth these Scriptures, (understand here, aswell a disputant of this world, being a talkative person amongst others, and persons whoever they be, he or she, who hath a form of godlinesse without the power thereof; as a publique Preaching man, being a false Prophet) For when for the time ye ought to be teachers, yee have need that one teach you again, which be the first principles of the Oracles of God, Heb. 5.12. And again, Son of man prophesy against the Shepherds of Israel, prophesy and say unto them, thus
saith the Lord God unto the Shepherds, wo be unto the shepheards of Israel, that doe feed themselves, Should not the Shepheards feed the flock? Ye eat the fatt, and cloath you with the wool, ye kill them that are fed, but yee feed not the flocke, Ezech. 34 2.3.

Again, a man in Christ, his language and works are spirit and life, because it is not he that speaketh or doeth, but the spirit of his heavenly father, which speaketh and doth in him, Mat. 10.20. But those who are not baptized into a man in Christ his baptisme, and yet will take the Kingdome of Heaven by violence, do weary themselves in an artificiall, historicall and painted Divinity, concerning which God sayeth, when yee come to appeare before me, Who hath required this at your hands, to tread my Courts; Isaiah 1 12. Some attaine to much of this Divinity, (as they call it) by the
eye, that is by reading the Books of such and such men, othe • s attain to much of it, by the Eare, that is, by hearing this, or that man, or gathering such & such expressions from one another, which they imitate; And others, do attain to much of it by their own conceptions, and self-will interpretations, and this tendeth to divisions & cooling of love amongst them exceedingly.

But all of you of this kind, in the meekenes, Gentlenes, and love of Christ, heare what his spirit sayth unto you, Behold ye despisers, and wonder, and perish, for I worke a work in your dayes, a worke which you shall in no wise believe, though a man declare it unto you, Act. 13.41. But I trust in God that some of you shall believe it; and I would to God that all of you, and I, and all mankind, did believe it aright.

div.head: CHAP. VI. That a man in Christ, is a true member of the true Church.
div.p: A Man born in one Country, & travelling through other far Countries, shall alwaies find, and see, that the inhabitants of those Countryes do differ nothing from the Inhabitants of that Country wherein he was born, in essence & essentiall properties, either in reasonable or unreasonable creatures: But that there is a fame-nesse, (so to speak) of essence and essentiall properties, in and amongst all the particular creatures, of every species & kind, whereupon th • s traveller may be, brought to admire the Creator, in his travelling amongst Gods creatures in other countries.

Now there are three things considerable in this Travellers life, the first is, he is no setled dweller, or member of any country, and yet in
some sence, he is a member of every Country, in which he hath been, and where he is.

The second is, as he liveth by the charity of mercifull hearted people who contributeth to the reliefe of his necessity, so he doeth (as it becometh him so to do) sometimes contribute to the necessity of a person being in greater want then he.

The third is, as he is willing to heare and receive sure and certain knowledge, from well experienced Inhabitants of the country, where he travelleth, so he is willing to communicate what he hath seen, and known in other countries, to them again, or to others who hath not known and seen such things; And so this harmlesse poor Traveller, is a beggar to some, and sometime a giver to others, a hearer to some, and sometime a speaker to others.

Even so, a man in Christ, being a Pilgrim and a Stranger, deare to God. doth find, feel, and see, the internall world in the externall, & beholdeth all created essences, and essentiall propertyes, to issue out, as sparckles and shadowes of the immense, infinite, and eternall essence which is God over all, blessed forever. Whereupon, his soule as oyntment is powred out upon the head of his Lord, and his body, as the Box is broken; that is, his soule is protended and carryed without the limits of himselfe and becometh a mysticall and spirituall Pilgrim, in and amongst the countries of the internall world, and there are three things considerable, in his happy and divine pilgrimage-life.

The first is, he is no setled dweller or member, of any country of the externall world, that is, he feeleth & seeth a more excellent way
then the most part of professing men do, who are rather setled upon the earth and externall world, that is, upon their own petty and particular Idols in the first place, and their own salvations in a mercinary way in the second place, then setled upon Christ; And yet in some sence he is a member of each country, place, or people, as a deare sojourner where ever he be.

The second is, as he is travelling amongst Gods creatures, he doth accurately observe and take speciall notice of God working, and manifesting himselfe in some People, & with those he will have most dear and intimate unity of spirit, & will receive their amiable and christian • difying word and worke: for it is manifested to him, that it is not they that do so, or speak so to him, but the spirit of their heavenly Father, which doth and speaketh so
to him; therefore in all subjection and lowlinesse of mind, he feeleth God in his love, and heareth God in his light, in and by such, and is so far from thinking it a disparagement to him, to be benefited either in word or worke by them, that with the two Disciples, going to Emmaus, his heart burneth within him, and is affected.

The third thing is, by the divine illuminating light, which leadeth into all truth, he is made very sencible of two things, the first is, that all persons into whom he cannot discern God manifesting himselfe, do stand in need to be brought to know & feel, that either their God must be glorified in them, that is, to work his will & work in them, which is their eternall happinesse, or else they are undone; The other thing is, he is obliged, by the vertue and heavenly constraint of the
operative love of Christ in him, (himselfe being converted and a follower of Christ) to become a Fisher of men, that is, to become all right things unto all men, that truth o • God may gain some, according to the divine truth of that Scripture. For though I be free from all men, ye • have I made my selfe a servant unto all that I might gain the more. And unto the Jewes I became as a Iew, that I might gain the Iewes, to them that are under the law, as under the law, that J might gain them that are under the law, to them that are without law, as without law, (being not without law to God, but under the law to Christ) that J might gain them that are without law; To the weak I became as weak, that J might gain the weak; J am made all things to all men, that J might by all meanes save some, 1. Cor. 9.19, 20. So that a man in Christ, is a member of any men in the world, either
in Christ, or not in Christ; if they be in Christ, he will be a subjected, lowly minded Disciple to them, if they be not in Christ, he will (as a deare sympathysing and pitifull commiserator) do his uttermost endeavours, to do them good, if they would receive it.

Thus was Paul and the Disciples true members of the true Church, and thus is a man in Christ a true member of the true Church; but those who are not baptised with a man in Christ, into a living active God, & a dead passive creature, do commonly either make a God of that wch is but the creature, that is, they thinke all is done if they be a member of such a church, as they thinke salvation belongeth unto, and herein while they doe as they doe (let none thinke here that I speak against the holy order and discipline of the true Church of
Christ) they are rather like unto young children, who with shels & little stones will imitate a reall building, then like true members of the •• ue Church, that is, called out of the world; for the word Church in the Greeke languge, being rightly interpreted, signifieth a calling out.

Or else, they account nothing of that which God accounteth dearly of, that is, they separate from such poor, sinfull, ignorant, People, as Christ the Lord God of mercy, free grace and love, did never separate from as they doe.

For although the Lord Christ did not stand in need of the most choysest Discipline of the creature, to be benefitted thereby, far lesse of their false worships; for then the candle should have given light to the Sun; then man should have been more perfect then his Maker; then the Pot should have framed the Potter;
then the blind should have led the seeing; yet he being the great light, and DAY SPRING, doth shine, to whom? Even to those that sit in the Region and shadow of death and darknes, Luke 1.79. He being the Physitian, he healeth whom? Even the sick; according to the divine truth of that Scripture, And it came to passe, as Jesus sate at meat in the House, behold many Publicans and sinners came and sate downe with him and his Disciples; And when the Pharisees saw it, they sayd unto his. Disciples, why eateth your master with Publicans and sinners? But when Jesus heard it, he said unto them, they that be whole need not a Physitian, but they that are sick, but go you and learn what that meaneth, I will have mercy and not sacrifice, for I am not come to call the Righteous, but sinners to repentance; Mat. 9.10.11.12.13.

He being the seeker, he seeketh, whom? Even the lost, according to the divine truth of that Scripture What man of you having an hundred sheep, if he loose one of them, doth he not leave the ninety nine in the wildernesse: and go after that which is lost, untill he find it, Luke 15.4.

It is true then, that those who make so little account of the day of small things, that is poor creatures in their ignorance and infirmities • et ayming at, & professing christinity, did never learn so at Christ; it may be some will object and say Is it not commanded that Saints should come out of Babel, and be separated? & the like; To which in loue & truth I answer; There are two sorts of Saints, the one reall, and they will separate from nothing except evill and sinne against God; The other nominall, and it is to be feared that they worship that inwardly,
from which they thinke they are separated outwardly, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Ther is a Generation that are pure in their own eyes, and yet are not washed from their filthynesse, Pro. 30.12. And againe And why beholdest thou the moat that is in thy brothers eye, but considerest not the beam that is in thine own eye, Math 7 3. A true Evangelicall Penitent will say here Lord be mercifull to me a sinner; but a proud Pharis • e will have much to say for himselfe.

div.head: CHAP. VII. That a man in Christ useth the world, that is, Being, Life, Sence, Reason, Food, Rayment, &c.
div.p:
A Person looking into a looking-glasse, and beholding the image of his face, may be said in the actuall use of the glasse, not to use it; that is, he is taken up with the
image, which he seeth in the glasse, and not with the consideration of of the glasse it selfe; and if he consider the glasse it selfe, while he be
• oldeth his image in it, if he consider it aright, he considereth it with relation to the reflecting and reverberating vertue which it hath in it, to let him see himselfe.

Even so, a man in Christ, useth all things without which he cannot subsist, as a looking glasse, in which he feeleth and seeth God to be the vertue of each of them, as the Being of his own Being, and all Beings else; the Life of his own life, and all lives else; the Sence of his own sence and all sence else? the Reason of his own reason, and all • eason else; the Food of his own food, & all food els, &c. according to the divine truth of that Scripture, For the invisible things of him, from the creation of the world, are clearly
seen, being understood by the thing • that are made, even his eternall power and God-head, Rom. 1.20.

Againe, look how much a person, looking into a glasse, and seeing his image, esteemeth his image inferiour to his face, the cause and substance of his image; even so much doth a man in Christ esteem himselfe, as he is himselfe inferiour to God, the eternall cause and substance, in being life, sence, reason, food, rayment, &c.

And herein he is like unto a man, who the more he lookes upon the Sun, the more he is dazled and made impotent in his naturall faculty of seeing: Or like unto a poor miserable creature, having committed notorious theft, in his King • intrustments, and is in the power and hands of the King, & the King in stead of rigour and justice, useth all clemency, and liberallity to him,
receiveth him into his house, giveth him all things good for him.

Now, by how much this good King is so gracious to him, and he made sensible of it, by so much this man may, and should stand in submission, and admiration of the King his goodnesse, and his own unworthinesse.

Even so is it with a man in Christ, in the injoyment of necessary things, he thinkes himself unworthy of any goodnesse, and injoyeth only the use of necessary things, as if he used them not, that is, he injoyeth and relisheth the vertue of God, in things meerly necessary. According to the divine truth of that Scripture, And they that use this world as though they used it not: for the fashion of this world goeth away, 1 Cor. 7.31.

But those, who are not baptised with a man in Christ, into a living acting God, and a dead passive creature
useth the world, that is, being, life, sense, reason, food rayment, &c. as a leacherous, seducing, and vainglorious Whore useth waters and oyntments to beautifie her face, for the satisfying her lustfull desires.

And as she useth a looking-glasse, in which when shee beholdeth her Image, shee falleth in love with that Image, because she thinketh that that Image, and her face, the substance of that Image is her owne.

And by how much a man in Christ, ascribeth all the vertue and excellency of created natures to God, as the eternall Fountaine: By so much doe those, who are not in Christ, ascribe to themselves, that is, they satisfie and please their owne carnall concupiscence in the unjust usurpation of those things which are proper to God.

And herein they are like unto a man, who having committed notorious
theft in the things which was intrusted to him by his King, and is in the power and hands of the King; and the King in stead of rigour and justice, useth all clemency and liberality towards him, receiveth him into his house, giveth him all good things which are necessary for him.

Now, in stead of standing in submission & admiration of the Kings free grace & goodnesse, and his own unworthinesse, he will be king himself, and assume unto himself as his own, the free & lovely conferred mercies of his good King, according to the divine truth of that Scripture. Let no man deceive you by any meanes, for that day shall not come, except there come a falling away. First, And that man of Sin be revealed, the son of perdition, who opposeth and exalteth himself above all that is called God, or that is worshipped, for that he as god, sitteth in the Temple of God, shewing himselfe
that he is god, 2 Thess. 2.3, 4.

So then, those that are not baptised with a man in Christ, in a living acting God, and a dead passive creature, are in the sight of God & truth no lesse theeves and usurping robbers, in being, life, sense, reason, food, rayment, &c. then those who being found guilty by the Jury are in the eyes of the Judge, sitting upon the Bench.

And in this unjust wickednesse & darknesse, the most part of men, yea, the whole world (set a few men in Christ aside,) lyeth, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Wee know that we are of God, and the whole world lieth in wickednesse, 1 Joh. 5.19.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. That a man in Christ, exerciseth himselfe in a calling.
div.p:
THere is a two-fold Calling in peoples outward conditions, the one is true, the other
false. The true Calling is such a calling, as the holy Lord God of truth putteth into the heart and hand of those who are men in Christ: And the end of this Calling is two-fold.

First, to doe good unto all, but especially to help the distressed, whether they be of the houshold of faith, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Do good unto all, but especially to those of the houshold of Faith, Gal 6.10. Or whether they appeare not to be of the houshold of Faith, but meere distressed creatures, whose necessities asketh, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Give to him that asketh, and from him that would borrow of thee, turne thou not away, that is, Give unto him, if thou be able, and hee bee in meere necessity, Mat. 5.42.

Secondly, to supply the meer necessities of himselfe and his, in regard that they who are not in Christ, will
not doe to him as hee would doe to them; and therefore he is exercised in a Calling by necessity. According to the divine truth of that Scripture, Provide for things honest in the sight of all men, Rom. 12.17.
And this Calling is very deare to God, because it is performed as a sacrifice to God.

The false calling, is such a calling, as the covetous, self-loving, and false spirit of error, putteth into the heart and hand of those who are not baptised with a man in Christ, in a living active God, and a dead passive creature. And this Calling, although it bear the name of a calling amongst the most part of men; yet in comparison of, and respect to, a true Calling, may be tearmed a calling, as Judas was termed one of the twelve, or as a false prophet may be termed a Prophet. And the end of this caling is two fold also.

First, principally and mainly to covet, love, and seeke his own good, & advantage in al the things he hath to doe with all men, more then the good and advantage of others; and to grumble and fret at the losse of his own good and advantage, in all the things he hath to do with all men. According to the divine truth of that Scripture; For the desire of money, is the root of all evill, which while some lusted after, they erred from the faith, and pierced themselves thorow with many sorrowes, 1 Tim. 6.10.

Secondly, to lay up treasures for themselves upon earth, and with the rich man, to say, Soule, soule, eat, drinke and be merry; never considering, what they are, and whose they are, and who is the true owner of those good things, which they make themselves Lords of; but either with that Epicurean person, which the spirit and wisedome of God calleth
the foole, which hath said in his heart there is not a God; are all gone out of the way? they are all corrupt, Psa. 14.3. Or else with Ananias and Saphira, they tempt the Spirit of the Lord in keeping away part of the price, that is, they will not forsake all, and sell all to be baptised with a man in Christ, into a living active God, and a dead passive creature, which is that blessed field, in which is hid, and to be found, the all-rich, and all-glorious, and all-sufficient everlasting pearle, and treasure even Christ, the joy, delight, and well-pleasing of the Father, then which, there is not such a treasure in heaven or earth.

div.head: CHAP. IX. That a man in Christ doth dye, that is, his soule and body are separated.
div.p:
AS there is a vast difference betwixt the life of a man in
Christ, and the life of those who are not in Christ, so is there no lesse difference betwixt their deaths.
A man in Christ, as was said before, is no farther a man in Christ, then the Holy Spirit of Christ is in him, (and if Christ be in him then the body is dead, that is, it is passive Rom. 8 10.)

Now, as Christ is in him, He is as willing, to returne againe into the bosome, (so to speak with reverence of the Immense, & glorious Majesty of the Incomprehensible Creator.) of his heavenly Father God, as his heavenly Father God, was willing to send him into, and set him upon the stage of this externall visible, world, into which and upon which he was set, after that he came from, and out of invisibility and silence, which was and is the mind and will of God.

To this invisibility and silence, (I
say) is a man in Christ, as willng to go as to live in the externall visible world, because his happy life is led, and lived in this internall, spirituall and invisible silence, that is, hee is dead, and his life is hid with Christ in God, and herein he is like unto a Kings sonne, whose father is pleased to send him to another country, for a certain time to be taught and trained up in such and such noble exercises as becommeth the sonne of such a father, now at the end of this certain time, he is as willing to returne againe to his father, as his father was willing to send him to that Country.

But those who are not baptised with a man in Christ, in a living active God, & a dead passive creature, are unwilling to leave being, life, sense, reason, belly-god-cheer, Mammon honor, wise, husband, children, friends, &c. because as theeves and
robbers, they do make all those their owne.

And herein they are like unto a miserably covetous merchant, going with a great summe of gold, to a Fair or Market, thinking to be a great gainer in his traffique, and as he is going, there commeth upon him an armed man, whom he is not able to resist, and demandeth of him his gold, which unlesse he doe presently give, he will presently kill him.

Now for feare of his life, he will give all his gold: but he doth not give it freely, but because he is terrified by and with the feare of death, and thinketh his life sweeter then death, or his gold, although before he came into this strait, his gold was sweeter to him then his life.

Even so is it with those who are not men in Christ, they doe leave and part with their life, as the Merchant,
giveth his Gold, and if so be they seeme to give it freely, yet this is that they may be Gainers, and get their soules to be saved.

But the Lord of truth, Christ, saith, Who loseth his soule, that is, who is baptised in a living active God, and a dead passive creature, shall find it, Luk. 9 24. for the divine baptisme, comprehendeth the chiefest good of the creature in it.
It is like unto, yea, it is that spirituall Arke of Noah, that is, Rest, into which, all that are, are preserved, but those that are out of it are miserable.

And thus far hath a man in Christ been paralelled with those men, who are Gods Creatures, some whereof, professing Christianity more eminently, then others, and some lesse, and some little or nothing at all, in those duties and practises of Religion, which they doe use to practise.

Now by the guidance of the holy Spirit of the God of truth, wee will endevour to parallel him with the same men in the light of understanding and judgement, concerning the controverted opinions, which are so much in agitation amongst them.

div.head: CHAP. X. That a man in Christ dearely loveth true understanding, judgments, and opinions, and yet he is united unto the higher Good.
div.p:
HAving formerly compared a man in Christ wi • h professing men, in the duties and practise of such performances, as they do usually exe • cise themselves into. We will by the vertue of the Spirit of God and truth, compare him with the same m • n in the understandings,
judgements, and opinions, which are amongst them.

It is true, a man in Christ loveth the knowledge of the truth, because the truth is in him; but yet hee is more united and inamoured, in, and with the spirit, life, and will of the truth, then of the notionall contemplation of true knowledge.

And herein he is like unto a deare sonne comming to his father, and speaking this language; O my father! for so much as you are the instrument, in, and by which God did beget me, educate me, love me, &c. So that I had, or have nothing of my selfe, but what I have received of you, I conceive that I, and all that I have, is yours, and not mine, and that it is just and right, that I and all that I have, should be imployed and live unto you, and according to your heart & will, and not live unto my selfe, and according to mine owne
heart and will, seeing all is yours.

Therefore, this is the summe of all my desires, ô my father! let me stand and live in the obedience and unity of your will and well-pleasing, for this onely is justice and equity; for whatsoever I desire, or would desire; whatsoever I have or would have; whatsoever I do or would do more then this, commeth of mine owne evill, and although I stand and live in the obedence and unity of your will and wel-pleasing, and not in my will and well-pleasing, I doe no more then that which becommeth a son to doe to his father, by divine Iustice, yea. I doe no more in my kind, then the Oxe which knoweth his owner, and the Asse which knoweth his masters crib in their kind, this language now doth wonderfully indeare, and rejoyce the loving father, that the son is become so sensible of God his goodnesse, and his own ingagement.
Even just so doth the life and language of a man in Christ, speake to God alone.

But those that are not baptised with a man in Christ, into a living act • ve God, and a dead passive creature, are in the knowledge of judgements and opinions, as they are in the use of being, life, sense, reason, food, raiment, &c. that is, they are more delighted, and exalted in the notionall contemplation of judgements and opinions, as they make for their owne glory and excellency of knowledge, (as they call it,) that they may sit at the right & left hand of Christ in all eternity, which is all but self and false christianity, then they are delighted in divine obedience, and self-abhorring, which is the covenant that God by Christ maketh with all true disciples, and is the only true christianity.

And hereunto they are like unto
a foolish son, comming to his father, and speaking this language, father ô how rich are you, and ô how rich shal I be, seeing I am your son: Now because I shall obtaine so great riches from you, it is sitting that I should have excellent knowledge of you every way; therefore father I pray you let me take a knife and rip up your belly, that I may know you perfectly how you are within, how your small gutts lye, how your joynts are coupled and the like.
This language now is so rediculous and contrary to reason, nature and truth, that the father will in no wise either approve or yeeld unto it.
Even just so doth the life and language of those who are not baptised with a man in Christ, into a living active God, and a dead passive creature, speak to God alone.

And therefore their clearest knowledge, is but ignorance of God and
Christ. According to the divine truth of that Scripture, and though I have the gift of prophesie, and understand all misteries, and all knowledge, and have no Charity, that is, not baptised in a living active God, and a dead passive Creature, I am nothing, 1 Cor. 13.2.
But a man in Christ feareth the Lord, and therefore the secrets of the Lord are with him. Psal. 25.14:

div.head: CHAP. XI. That a man in Christ believeth that there is one God, and this God is Vnity in Trinity, and Trinity in Vnity, That is, God in Father, Son and Spirit, and Father, Sonne and Spirit, in God.
div.p:
O Thou true eternall Light! whose self manifests thy selfe to all those who have any true manifestation
of thee, even as the Sun, (being a representative sparkle of that immense glorious Light which thou art,) manifesteth it selfe by it self, to all those who have any true • anifestation of it. Arise in the lovely Majesty of thy more then excellent splendor, and let the thick misty clouds of sin and ignorance, which stand as a partition wall, betwixt the glory of thy admirable nature and holy God-head, and the blinded eyes of the understandings of thy poore creatures, be dispersed and annihilated: The clouds of sin and ignorance, I say, O most holy Goodnesse, which they themselves, and not thou, have set up as idols in their hearts, & as stumbling blocks before their faces, & loveth darknes rather then thee, the true everlasting Light wch shineth in the darknesse, and the darknesse comprehendeth thee not.

A man in Christ, as hee is man, seeth matter of deepe admiration, not onely in the more noble and greater, but also in the meanest and smallest of the creatures which liveth, either in the earth, water, aire, or fire; each particular and individuall living creature of every species and kind, containing in it selfe as in a mysterious little world or creation, the earth, water, aire and fire, in a corporeall composition, and all of them in a vast variety of vertuous faculties and diverse operations.

Now if he be dazled here, (& wel may hee be) unto what inutterable and absolute admiration shall he be brought into, in comprehending the incomprehensible, in seeing the invisible, in searching the unsearchable, in terminating the infinite and transcendent Creator, who can no more be reached unto, by the creature
his comprehensive ability then the Sunne can be reached unto, by the arme of creature man.

And this deepe admiration of the creatures, and absolute admiration of the Creator, is caused to him, as hee himselfe is a particular created creature, that is, an Individuall person, amongst the innume
• able and various multitudes of other creatures, wherein the almightinesse and boundlesse largenesse of the wonderfull Father and Creator appeareth.

But as he is in Christ, baptised in a living active God, and a dead pas
• ive creature, that is, translated out of the kingdome of darknesse into the Kingdom of his deare Son; He i •• oyned to the Lord, and one Spirit with the Lord, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, but he that is joyned to the Lord, is one spirit, 1 Cor. 6.17. And this spirit searcheth
the deepe things of it self, and nothing else, 1 Cor. 2 10, 11.

This way he is a fearer of the Lord, and the secrets of the Lord are with him, Psal. 25 14. This way God saith within him and to him as he said to A • raham, shall I hide from my beloved creature, being baptised in the true name of my infinitely dearely beloved sonne, that thing which I doe, Gen. 18.7. that is, what I am according to the divine truth of that Scripture, He that hath my Commandements, and keepeth them, (that is he that is baptised in a living active God, and a dead passive creature,) he it is that loveth me, and he that loveth me, shall be loved of my Father, and I will love him, and will manifest my selfe to him, Joh. 14.21.
In this divine union, and blessed Baptisme, doth a man in Christ, by Christ truly feele, know and see these two maine things:

First, That this whole visible University or World, with all, and every part of it in its beauty & perfection, (and O how beautifull and • erfect is it) being adorned with such innumerable and various mul
••• udes of severall kindes of crea
• ures, is a visible representation, of he invisible, incomprehensible, un
• earchable and infinite Being of all beings, which is Jehovah, God the • reator; according to the divine truth of that Scripture: For the invisible things of him, from the creation of the world are clearely seene, being understood by the things that are made, even his eternall power and God-head, Rom 1.20.

And this whole beautifull and • erfect University, or world, with every individuall part thereof in its formal being and operative faculty • oth issue and flow out of the Creator, because he is God, (that is,
absolute, beautifull, perfect goodnesse and love,) by a necessity, for goodnesse must doe good, by a necessity, and love must extend this goodnesse without it selfe, by a necessity, and cannot do otherwise.
Even as the Sunne doth shine by a necessity, and extendeth its light out of it selfe, to and for the good of all things, which it produceth by a necessity.

And no man truly feeleth, knoweth, and seeth, this eternall power and godhead, of the invisible, incomprehensible, unsearchable, and infinite power, and godhead by the things that are made, but he that is baptised in a living active God, and a dead passive creature, and that is only a man in Christ.

Secondly, A man in Christ, doth truly feele, know, and see, that as it is altogether impossible to the rationall creature man, as man, to ascend
up, and comprehend the Sun, which cannot be comprehended by man, but it comprehendeth man, that is, it extendeth its light unto, and upon man, and so man may be said to comprehend the Sun.

Even so, impossible is it to the rationall creature man as man, to comprehend the incomprehensible, invisible, unsearchable, and infinite Being of all beings, which is God over all, blessed for ever. Unlesse he should manifest his incomprehensiblenesse, invisiblenesse, unsearchablenesse, and infinitenes, into such a manifestation, as the rationall creature man may be in some measure capable of him.

Now because amongst the rationall creatures, Father, Son, and Spirit, which Spirit is life, motion, and action, are most sencible and united relations, the one whereof manifesteth the other, for a Father
is not a Father without a Son; and a Son is not a son without a Father; and a Spirit, that is, life, motion, & action, is not a spirit without father and son

Therefore the incomprehensible invisible, unsearchable, and infinite Being of all beings, who is the true cause and author of these relations, in and amongst the rationall creatures doth make out, or manifest himselfe in these three relations; that the rational creature man, may by this meanes be made capable in some measure to comprehend the nature of him, who is the true eternall and essentiall nature of all created natures & in this he is truly called the father, and eternall Creator.
And to comprehend the love of him, who is the true eternall and essentiall love of all loves, and in this he is truly called the son.

And to comprehend the life, motion,
and action of him- who is the true, eternall, and essentiall life, moton and action of all lives, motions and actions; and in this he is truly called the holy Spirit.

Now, as amongst mortall creatures, a father is not a father without a son, so the true eternall and essentiall Nature of all Natures, which is the father, is not the true eternall and essentiall Nature of all natures, without the true eternall and essentiall Love of all loves, which is the Son.

And as a son is not a son without a father, so the true, eternall and essentiall love of all loves, which is the son, is not the true eternall, and essentiall love of all loves, without the true eternall, & essentiall nature of all natures, which is the Father.

And as a Spirit which is life motion, and action, is not a Spirit, without Father and Son; so the true
eternall & essentiall life, motion, & action, of all lives, motions; and actions, which is the holy spirit, is not the true eternall and essentiall life, motion and action of all lives, motions, and actions, without the true eternall, and essentiall nature of all natures, which is the Father, & and the true eternall and essentiall love of all loves, which is the Son.

So then, the incomprehensible, invisible, unsearchable and infinite Power and God-Head is manfested for the capacity of the rationall creature man, into Father, Son, and Spirit; which three Relative manifestations, are unto the incomprehensible, invisible, unsearchable and infinite power and God-head, as the externall written word is unto the internall Spirit and life, unto which the externall written word is a testimony; according to the divine truth of that Scripture
Search the Scriptures, for in them yee think to have eternall life, and they are they that testify of me, Joh. 5.39.

Even so, this threefold manifestation, is a testimony of the incomprehensible, invisible, unsearchable and infinite eternall power, and God-head, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, There are three that bear Record in Heaven, that is, of this incomprehensible, invisible, unsearchable and infinite eternall power and God head, the Father; the Word, that is the Son, and the holy Spirit, & these three are one,
• . Ioh. 5.7.
Now by these last words, These three are one, is holden out, That as God is unity in Trinity, that is, God in Father, Son and Spirit, So God is Trinity in unity.

And here shineth, as the bright Sun, amongst Moon and Starres, THAT GLORIƲS MYSTERY
of all MYSTERIES, namely, as the Father is in the Son, so the Son is in the Father; according to the divine truth of that Scripture, That they all may be on • as thou father art in me, and I in the, Ioh. 17.21. And again, Beleeve me, that J am in the Father, and the Father in me. Ioh. 14.11.

And as the Father and the Son are in the holy Spirit; so the holy Spirit is in the Father and the Son; Even as the heat which floweth out of the essentiall Fire, acting upon a combustible matter; as the Fire is in the Heat, otherwise it should not be heat: so that Heat is in the Fire, otherwise it should not be heate, that is motion, and action of the essentiall Fire, acting upon a combustible matter; according to the divine truth of that Scripture, And hereby wee know that he abideth in us, by the Spirit that he hath given us,
Joh. 3.24. And again, For what man knoweth the things of a man, save the Spirit of a man which is in him, even so the things of God knoweth no man, but the Spirit of God, 1. Cor. 2.11.

So then, as the incomprehensible invisible, unsearchable, and infinite eternall power and Godhead, is for the capacity of the rationall creature-man, manifested into unity in Trinity; that is, God in Father, Son, & holy Spirit, So he is Trinity in unity, that is, Father, Son, & Spirit in God; according to the divine truth of that Scripture, These three are one, 1. Ioh. 5.7.

And as no man truly feeleth knoweth and seeth the eternall, power and Godhead, of the incomprehensible, invisible, unsearchable and infinite God, by the things th • t are made, except a man in Christ: so there is no man that truly feeleth knoweth, and seeth, the true misterious
manifestaton of one God, to to be unity in Trinity; That is God in Father, Son, and Spirit and Trinity in Unity; that is, Father, Son, and Spirit, in God, Except a man in Christ.

All others, that is, who are not baptised with a man in Christ, in a living active God, and a dead passive creature, do make Idols of the creatures and a monster of the God of the creatures; according to the divine truth of these Scriptures, Who changed the truth of God into a lye, and worshipped and served the creature more then the Creator, who is blessed for ever, Amen, Rom. 1.25. And again, They have set up a King, but not by me, they have made Princes, & J knew it not; of their silver & their gold have they made them Idols, Hos. 8.4. Let the wicked forsake his way, and the unrighteous man his thoughts, and let him return unto the Lord, and
he will have mercy upon him: and to our God, for he will abundantly pardon; For my thoughts are not your thoughts neither are your wayes my wayes, saith the Lord; for as the Heavens are higher then the earth, so are my wayes higher then your waies, & my thoughts then your thoughts, Isaiah 55.7. The meaning of which words, according to God and truth, are to be interpreted thus.

Let no wicked and unrighteous man; that is, who is not baptised in a living active God, and a dead passive creature, think, that he can more possibly conceive aright of, or be united to God, who is Unity in Trinity, and Trinity in Unity, then it is possible to him, being a heavy earthy creature; to jump up thorow the heavenly Skie; But if he forsake his own way & his own thoughts, that is, if he be baptised in a living active God, and a dead passive creature,
then he getteth the mercy and grace, to feele, know and see in truth and union, this MYSTERY, which no man knoweth; or can know, but a man in Christ.

div.head: CHAP. XII. That a man in Christ, is baptised in the name of the Father, Son, and holy Spirit, and believeth that this only, and no other, is the true baptisme.
div.p:
A Regenerate man in Christ, in his spirituall life, may be truly compared to a generate man in his naturall life; concerning which naturall man, observe these three things; The first is his generation, and by his Father. Without wch he can neither be a nursed child or a ripe strong man. The second is, his education, that is, his nursed condition, and this is an act of love, acted by the generator, upon the
generated, to the advancement of the generated, unto his ripe age and strength of body, without wch he cannot be a ripe strong man, & this education is the end of generation.
The third is, his mature corroberation, that is his ripe age and strength of body; and this mature coroboration, is the end of his education.

Even so, (if we may speak of the truths & holy mysteries of God, by way of similitudes) is a man in Christ baptised in the name of the Father, Son and holy Spirit; and seeing it is of concernment to speak in particular, how a man in Christ is bapti- in each of these three names.

O thou true Father, and eternal author of divine Generation! Without whose lovely drawing no man can come unto, or know the Son Christ, and holy Spirit; let the
lively influence of thy divine light, and quickning vertue, be a testimony and unerring guide, to discover to thy poor creatures, how a man in Christ is baptised in thy name.

A man before he be in Christ, is first, like unto, yea he is that man who neither is, or hath any thing of himselfe, neither body or members, neither soule or faculties, but is a meer absolute created nature made by the Creator, who is perfect goodnes and love; according to the divine truth of that Scripture; Cease you from man whose breath is in his nostrils, for wherein is he to be accounted of Isaiah 2.22.

Secondly, he is like unto, yea he is that man of sin, who opposeth & exalteth himselfe above all that is called God; 2. Thes. 2.4. that is, he calleth and accounteth light darknes, and darknes light, all that he doeth is better then that which either
God or Gods People doth; In his own estimation he is the only thing that is best: and ought to be loved and honoured; If he be made a God by any creature, that is, honoured, loved, reverenced; and yet his own will and delight satisfyed, he rejoyceth exceedingly, and maketh a God of that creature, for no other end, but that that creature should make a God of him in every thing, wherein he desireth, to be made a God of; And so he runneth on in this his fierce and deluded course; Either with the Prodigall Son, in the lust of the eye, in the lust of the fl • sh, and pride of life; Or in a burning zeal with Saul, breathing out threatnings and slaughter against the Disciples of the Lord; Or in hypocrisie with Jehu, and the Pharisees. But now, whil'st this poor mad, deluded creature, (who afterwards by grace becometh a
man in Christ) is posting on in darknes and iniquity, there cometh some certain happy moment of time, in the which it is with the soul of him as it is with a young Woman, which in a naturall way is wounded and ravished with the love of a comely and proper man, so that there is a holy flame and divine extasie ingendred, and this soule is exercised with some unspeakeable lovely agony, and yet it cannot well tell, what is the matter with it; and here there is a voice which in majesty, spirit, and life, calleth and saith, stand sinner, and this word stand, is the eternall word of the Father, saying, let there be light in the Micro-chaos, that is, in the sinner possessed with this darknes and iniquity, and there is light; Whereupon is straight presented unto this POOR SOUL its own great misery, and its fathers great
mercy; its own abounding sin, and its Fathers superabounding grace; here is presented Heaven and Hell; here is joy and sorrow; here is fire and wax; here is the sinner (like Saul) smitten [blind] down to the ground, hearing this sound, sinner, sinner, why persecutest thou me? Here is the sence of the swinish food: & the sence of the fathers House; In short, here is such a work in this new foundation: as no man can speak, or think of aright, but only he that hath felt it.

Now as every thing which is manifest & produced, tendeth toward its own first matter, and principle again: even so this divine fundamentall manifestation of the eternall light, beginneth to tend towards it selfe, so that the yeelding soule incordiall love, beginneth with halting Jacob, tongue ty'd Moses, and blind Saul, to say, what
is thy Name? And who art-thou ô Lord? And in this question, (ō admiration!) a certain divine knowledge desiring to know, asketh this question. To which in cordiall love is answered, I am the Father, and thy Father, that is, the true eternall Nature of all Natures; all created natures are mine, which are in heaven, earth, and Sea, and by them my eternall power and Godhead, should be understood; by my rationall creature man; upon whom I have bestowed more Donations & indowments; then unto all other inferiour Creatures, which live either in the earth water, ayre or fire; and all the created natures of my universall world, abideth in their first estate of their creation; that is, they are all very good, and no way repugnant to my will; that is they call no vertue or faculty which is performed in any of them, their
own: nor do they exalt or admire themselves in these donations and indowments, which I have given them, but every one of them spending and changeing themselves for the good of another; as if (and it is most true) they were not created for themselves, or for their own good, but for the good of another.

This is my will, in this I am glorifyed, in this I am manifested to be the Creator: and the w •• e of my hands to be the creature; In this all my creatures are and have nothing in themselves, and are and have all, and whatsoever they are and have in me; Thus I fill the heaven, earth, water, ayre and fire, with my goodnes; Thus I AM THE LORD, and there is none beside me, and my glory will I not give to another.

But now, ō thou my reasonable creature man! In whom my eternall power & Godhead, should &
ought to have been most conspicuously manifested; thou who should have been amongst other inferiour creatures, as the Moon, yea, the Sun amongst the Starres, as my more noble and more excellent creature who as thou art my creature-man, I have made as a sustemm, or compend of the whole visible world, containing in thy selfe the Being, Vegitation and Sences of all inferiour crea ••• es; And moreover, out of my Fatherly wel-pleasing Will, have crowned thee with the divine faculties of an immortall and rationall Spirit, that thou shouldest understand, feel, know, and see my eternall power and Godhead, by the things that are made; that is, the creatures; and that thou shouldest (in a more noble & excellent manner, by how much I have made the a more noble & excellent creature, then all the inferiour creatures)
have bidden in me, and have been no way repugnant to my will; that is not to thinke and call any thing thine own, whether body or soule, or any thing that belongs to either, nor to have exalted and admired thy selfe, in whatsoever thou art or hath; for whatsoever thou essentially art or hath, is mine and not thine; but with the same ayre, water, earth, candle, and all other irrationall creatures, to have been for the good of others, and not for thy selfe; thou that shouldest have been the mirrour of all the irrationall creatures, even thou art most irrationall, yea, thou art worse then irrationall, for thou art ante-father, that is, against me God the Father, thou wilt be something thy selfe, yea, thou wilt be the father thy selfe thou wilt exalt & admire thy selfe, thou wilt be mainly for thy own proper selfe, and selfe-good; thus
thou art against my will, thus thou derogates from my glory, thus am I not manifested to be the Creator, and thou the creature; thus I am not all, and thou nothing; thus I am not the Lord, but there is some besides me; thus my glory is felloniously usurped by another, and I appeall to thy own understanding, & conscience, whether it be so or not.

Now the yeelding soule, overcome by the authority of the Father his answer, making the soule in some measure capable of his fatherly nature, weepeth through joy and rejoyceth through mourning, and uttereth this language.

O Father and fountaine of pure goodnes, love and truth; I am overcome, O I am overcome, and convinced; O what wilt thou doe with me, who have been a horrible Rebell against thy fatherly goodnes,
love and truth, who have set my selfe in thy seat, and made my selfe my God; O what Hell is suffient to revenge thy divine justice upon me? But alas! Why say I so? I feel, know and see now by thy most holy, and pure truth, that my disobedience to thy divine will is the cause and evill of Hell, Oh that I had never been born to my selfe, Oh what shal I doe, Oh mercy, mercy.

And thus is this soul brought into a holy agony, and divine indignation, and desperation against it selfe, so that it abhorreth sinfull selfe, & sweetly embraceth holy truth; and thus, it is baptised in the name of the Father; thus the Father draweth to thee Son, and this is the first divine generation, without which none is, or can be rightly stated in the true filiation, or nursed condition of divine education.

Now as the new born infant, when it commeth into this world, standeth in an absolute necessity of food & yet of it selfe can neither think, speak, or perform any meanes for its food, but lives by, and upon the food which the tender hearted and loving Parent nurse feedeth it withall, as an impotent passive creature.

Even so, a new regenerated child of God, wakened and raysed up out of sin and ignorance, by the lovely Majesty, and over-coming truth of the Father; And seeing the Father to be the true owner & possessour of all things spirituall & earthly; and the creature to be nothing, of and by it selfe; doth now feel, know, and see an absolute necessity, to be baptised in the name of the Father, that is, to let the Father have his own will in all things, and in all conditions; But
now by the vertue of this divine BAPTISME, he feeling, knowing an seeing in himselfe, the Diabolicall selfe seeking, and self-loving power, or rather impotency, and delusion of the old Serpent, creature man; He doth likewise feele, know, and see, that of himselfe he can neither thinke, speake, or use any meanes, for the manageing of his new regenerated baptisme; And therefore the true eternall nature of all natures, even the father, in whose selfe and name he is now regenerated and baptised becometh unto him the true eternall love of all loves, that is Iesus Christ, to be his nursing Saviour, and teaching Master, who for his sake, AND ALL TRUE PENITENT SINNERS that they might be of his mind, and made capable in some measure of his ETERNALL LOVE,
made himselfe of no reputation, & tooke upon him the forme of a servant, and was made in the likenesse of man, and being found in fashion as a man, he humbled himselfe, & became obedient unto death, even he death of the Crosse, Phil. 2.7.

And again, the soul being re-born and baptised in the name of the Father, becometh a dearly beloved child, and Disciple of Iesus Christ; unto whom all power that is in heaven & earth is given, as he pronounceth himselfe, Math. 28.18. Here now is his Anchoring-place, betwixt the absolute necessity on the one, hand, and the absolute impossibility on the other hand.

And here, as the loving nursing Parent is delighted in feeding & educating the child: & as the child is enamor'd & delighted in the feeding upon, and educating of the Parent,
by the substance & vertue of whose flesh, and bones, the child liveth; Even so, Jesus Christ, the true, eternall lovely son, and love it selfe, is delighted and rejoyced in spirit, when the sonne, which no man knoweth but the Father, and the Father which no man knoweth but the Sonne, is revealed unto regenerate babes Luke 10.21, 22. and again regenerate babes, eating the flesh and drinking the bloud, John. 6.54. that is, feeding upon Christ, are members of his body, of his flesh, and of his bones, Ephe. 5.30.

But now as it is natural to a child, who is dearly beloved and carefully nursed by the parent, to grow presumptuous, by the indulgency of the parent and extravagant in pleasing its own humours and phancy, as to jumpe out of the armes of the parent into the fire or water, or to affect things which are not good
for it selfe, and as it is naturall to the wise loving parent to moderate indulgency and in wisdome and love to restraine extravagancy.

Even so it is incident to a regenerate babe in Christ, to grow exalted above moderate measure, through the abundance of light and love, and extravagant in its desires, and affections to satisfie its own selfe in spirituall selfinesse.

But Iesus Christ the Annointed Saviour of his people, and true mortifier of all selfinesse, and exaltation of flesh and spirit in them, as he is the nurse he feedeth, and as he is the master, he teacheth his owne deare child and disciple after this manner.

O thou the object and subject of the secrets and true light of the Father! O thou the object and subject of my love! who am one with the Father, and in the Father, and the
Father in me! Wouldest thou walk worthy of thy Father, who hath made thee his owne deare child and son, by grace and favour? Wouldest thou walk worthy of thy son-ship and high calling? Wouldest thou be truly filiated, and make the calling and election of thy divine regeneration, and baptisme in the name of the father sure.

Then looke unto me & my lovely life, who for thy sake and restauration, that thou mightest be baptised in the external love of the father which is in my name, and that the same mind should be in thee which was also in mee, although I being the brightness of the father his glory, and the expresse Image of his person, and upholding all things by the word of my power. And although I being in the forme of God thought it not robbery to be equall with God. Yet made my selfe of no
