reputation, and tooke upon me the forme of a servant, and was made in the Likenesse of man, and being found in fashion as a man, I humbled my selfe, and became obedient unto death, even the death of the crosse, holding and pointing out unto thee and all true children and Disciples, that as none can come unto me except the father draw him, so no man commeth to the father but by me.
So that the eternall love of and to the Father, must overcome, Mortifie, neglect, and annihilate, all self-love and exaltation, whether in Temporall or Spirituall.

And shall the disciple be above his master? shall I make my self of no reputation, according to my lovely will which is the will of the father, and shall my disciple bee great in reputation? shall I in assuming a mysterious person like unto, and in fashion as a man, be as
it were a shaddow in my outward man, in the visible world, Though the compleat and full substance of the invisible world in my inward man, and shall my disciple be great in the visible world, in rejoycing in, or united unto, any thing in it? Shall I be humbled and my disciple exalted? Shall I become obedient unto the death, even the death of the Crosse; and shall my disciple have gloriation and pleasure? Shall my gloriation and divine pleasure, be onely in the resignation and selfe deniall of resignation and selfe-denyall? And shall my disciple live in non-resignation and selfness? Shall I be poor, and my disciple rich? Shal I mourn, through the sense of the sinnes of others, and shall my disciple laugh, being unsensible of his owne sinne? Shall my Crowne bee in the holy Crosse, and shall my disciple have his crowne in lying vanities? Shall
I as a Mysterious Man, and Redeemer of man, bee nothing in my Manhood, and shall my disciple be somthing in himself & manhood? Shall the Foxes have holes, and the birds nests, but I have nothing wherupon to lay my head; and shall my disciple have any thing to lay his head upon? Shall I come not to do my owne will; and shall my disciple do his owne-will? Shall I be dead and passive, and shall my disciple be alive and active?

Now the regenerate soule being illuminated and baptised before in the name of the father, becometh no lesse inamoured, indeared, and affected with this holy and heavenly life, of the sweet and lovely Lord God Christ, then it was with the blessed and joyfull illiumination of the Father of lights, and so is baptised in the name of the sonne, and becommeth separated and translated
out of the kingdome and element of its owne self-something, selfe love, and selfe-will, into the kingdom and element of the father his selfe-all-nesse, his selfe-love, and his selfe-will,

And this true divine food and discipline, being sweetly and kindly rellished, and in a divine manner (so to speak, & the Spirit of God speaketh so in the Scripture) made the flesh and bones of the soule and body, causeth the life and language of this dearly Beloved Babe-disciple, to utter and expresse it selfe even in such a likenesse & sweet same-nesse of mind with Christ, as there is a likenesse and similitude, betwixt the natural nursing parent, and the nursed child.

So that the same mind is in it, which was also in Christ, and this divine education of Christ, is to be truly baptised in his Name, which
baptisme is the end of being regenerated of the Father, and without which none is, or can be baptised in the Name of the Holy Spirit.

Now as the child first generated, and afterwards nursed and fed, becommeth an able strong person, to be imployed in and about the affaires and businesses of his parents; even so a man in Christ baptised in the Name of the Father, that is, regenerated of and by the Father, and baptised in the Name of the Sonne, that is, educated and nursed up in the life & love of, and to the Father alone, becommeth to bee an able strong person, (in comparison of meere creature man) in, and about the affaires and businesses of the Father and Son.

So that hee is no more now for himself, but for the good of others, he that was before the object of attendance & education, becommeth
now an attendant and educating instrument to attend, and educate others. He that was in the way of strengthning before, is now become the strengthener of others, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, therefore when thou art converted, strengthen thy brethren. Luke 22.32. though he bee free from all men, yet he becommeth now a servant unto all, that he may win the more, hee becommeth unto the Jewes as a Jew, that he may winne the Jewes, to them that are under the Law, as though he were under the Law, that he may winne them that are under the Law. To them that are without Law, as though he were without Law, (when he is not without Law as petaining to God; but is in the Law through Christ.) That he may win them that are without Law. To the weak he becommeth as weak, that he may win
the weak. He is made all things to all men, that he may by all meanes save some According to the divine truth of that Scripture, which w •… cited in the sixth Section.

And thus is he baptised in the Name of the holy Spirit, which is the end of his being baptised, in the Name of the Son, as his being baptised in the Name of the Son is the end of his being borne of, and baptised in the Name of the Father.

But those that with a man in Christ, are not baptised in a living active God, and a dead passive creature, are deluded and deceived, in their being baptised in each of those three Names, for first the false light of the false father deceiveth them, that is, they will not let the true Father have his fatherly prerogative in them, but they will appropriate, will, love, possesse, and act something themselves. Secondly,
the false love of the false christ deceiveth them, that is, they love themselves better then the Father. Thirdly, the false life of the false spirit deceiveth them, that is, they doe not love their neighbour as themselves.

And albeit, there be many and diverse Religions and Baptismes amongst many and diverse people of the habitable world: yet to be baptised with a man in Christ, truly and essentially in the Name of the Father, Son, & Holy Spirit, is only the best; all others are not the best.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. That a man in Christ, hath his eternall well-being in Christ, and believeth that all men in whom Christ is, and they in Christ, have their eternal wel-being in Christ.
div.p:
AS the members of the body, and branches of the tree, have
their originall being in the body and tree, but their operative welbeing in the spirit and life of the body and tree.

Even so a man in Christ hath his originall being in God, but his operative well being in the spirit & life of his God: So that albeit a man in Christ, doth feele, know, and see his being in the being of all beings. which is his God and Creator, (and O how unspeakeably good is it to feele know, and see it so) yet is his chiefe felicity not altogether placed in his originall being, but in his operative welbeing: that is, in the spirit and life of his God and Saviour.

It is his ioy and his crowne, to be acted as a dead passive creature, in & by the Spirit of God, as the members of the body and branches of the tree, which are dead and passive in themselves, and have no motion, action, or fruitfulnesse, but what
motion, action, and fruitfulnesse, they have in, and by the Spirit and life of the body and tree.

Thus his salvation and eternall well-being is wrought in him by the spirit and life of his God, who is the only worker of it, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Workout your own salvation with fear and trembling, for it is God which worketh in you both to will and to do of his good pleasure, Phil. 2.13.

Now as a man in Christ being baptised in a living active God, and a dead passive creature, hath his eternall well-being in his head and Lord Christ, who saves him without himselfe, yet in himselfe; even so hee beleeveth that all men in Christ thorow the whole world, of what Nation or people soever they be, have their eternall well-being in Christ, according to the divine truth of that Scripture; Then Peter
opened his mouth and said, Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of persons, but in every Nation he that feareth him and worketh righteousnesse; that is, he that is baptised in a living active God, & a dead passive creature, is accepted with him, Ast. 10.34, 35.

But he beleeveth, (and it is most true) that al men thorow the whole world, of what Nation or people soever they be, that are not in Christ and Christ in them, although they have their originall being in God, that is, although there being, life, senses, reason, and the like, doe all belong to God, the true being of all beings, the true life of all lives, the true sense of all senses, the true reason of all reasons: Yet unlesse their being, life, senses, reason, and the like be unto God, as the members of the body, and branches of the tree, (which are the organs or instruments,
in and by which the spirit and life of the body acteth. Its spirit and life-operation, and the spirit & life of the tree, acteth its spirituall • egitation and fruitfulnesse) are un
• o the body and tree; they have not their operative welbeing in God. The reason is, that their operative being unto God, as the members ate unto the body, and the branches unto the tree, is their only best, and eternal welbeing. This is the judgement and divine light of a man in Christ, touching the point called generall Redemption, which is so much agitated amongst some persons, and these not of the meanest note of profession; and therefore they shall do well to take heed with all diligence unto the truth of Jesus in this point; for unlesse they be baptised with a man in Christ, in a living active God, and a dead passive creature, and so be unto God,
as the members are unto the body, and the branches unto the tree, in stead of holding out generall re-Redemption to all others, they may come short of particular Redemption, that is, eternall welbeing themselves. A man in Christ, Paul by name, thought it no disparagement to say so of himselfe, in holding out the Gospell of Christ to others: But I keepe under my body, and bring it into subjection, lest that by any meanes when I have preached to others, I my selfe should be a cast-way, 1 Cor. 9.27. And I dare say, that the Apostle was as truly honest, as any in this generation who professeth discipleship.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. That a man in Christ doth feel, know, and see in himselfe, that as he is a creature, that is, of himself, he can neither will nor do good. But as he is a creature, that is, himselfe, he can both will and doe evill, and the same doth he believe of all other men, as they are creatures, that is, themselves. Againe, as he is in Christ, he doth scele, know, and see in himselfe that he •… oth can and will doe good through Christ, which strengtheneth him, and cannot in complacency, will and doe evill, and the same doth he believe of all other men in Christ.
div.p:
AS a mans hand which is altogether without skil in writing, can neither performe meane writing nor good writing of it selfe, but whilst it is in another hand which is very
skilfull and leadeth it, it can by its owne rude and extravagant motions marre and deface the life and vigour of true writing.

And as a mans hand wch is altogether without skil in writing, becomes as it were dead & passive, in the hand of a most skilfull writer, through the vertuous faculty and skil of the leading hand, performeth a caracter and shape of letter, according to the life and vigor of true writing.

Even so a man in Christ, as he is a creature, that is, as he is himselfe is like unto a hand which is altogether without skil in writing, and can no more will, or act, divine operations, then the rude hand can perform true writing.

And as the rude hand, although it hath motion and action in it selfe, yet it is so irregular & extravagant in motion, and so be stirring in it selfe whilst it should be redacted into a
cessation & silence in the hand of the most skilfull true writer, that it is so far from true writing, that it impeadeth and marreth the true caracter and shape of the letter.

Even so a man in Christ as he is man and creature, that is, himselfe, is so irregular, and extravagant in all his faculties and operations, that he doth rather impead, and marre divine operation, then otherwise.

Againe, as a mans hand which is altogether without skill in writing, becommeth as dead and silent in and to the hand of the skilfull writer, as the pen is dead and silent in and to this same rude hand, although his hand be vnskilfull and ignorant, yet by the leading power and skilfull faculty of the hand of the powerfull and skilfull writer, there is performed such writing, as the master writer is well pleased withall.

Even so a man in Christ, becomming
as dead and silent in and to God, as the dead and silent pen, is in and to the hand, although he be in himselfe impotent and ignorant, yet he is made to bring forth such fruits in Christ, as is well pleasing to God the Father.
And here commeth three questions, shortly and briefely to be propounded and answered.
The first is, what the leading hand requireth of the hand to be led, whether active motion or passive silence.
Ans. Passive silence.
The second is, what the leading hand affecteth and would be at, when and whilst it is conjoyned with the hand to be led, whether activ •… motion, or passive silence.
Ans. Active motion.
The third is, whilst the led hand is agitated, moved and led in the act of writing, whether is it active or passive?
Ans. In regard of it selfe, it is passive, in regard of the leading hand, it is active, and therefore it is actively passive, and passively active.
It is even so in the state of life, and judgement of light of a man in Christ, concerning this point called Co-operation, which is so much agitated and controverted in these times.

Some do too much affect to have the pen write without the hand, and others to have the hand write without the pen, but none of these is the better way, for Christ the Lord and eternall truth saith, I in you and you in me, as the branch cannot beare fruit of it selfe, except it abide in the vine, 〈◊〉 more can yee, except you abide in me, as was cited before in the first Section.

div.head: CHAP. XV. That a man in Christ doth fee know, and see in himselfe that Go •… doth love him, forbid him of evill and offereth mercy and health to his misery, sinfull sicknesse and death, and believeth the same of all others.
div.p:
GOd the Father and a man in Christ (if we may speak of the Holy mysteries of God, after the manner of men, and in parables) may be truly compared, as a loving father, who is dearly in love with his owne child and son, which son when he is capable to understand good from evill, the bowell-hearted father labours by all meanes of dearest love to keepe and save from evill, and to advance him in God; now there is a whore-house not far off, and the father well knowing the
pronenesse of the beloved son to be such as may easily be insnared, by the seducing whore, and be not only infected with the contagious and filthy disease which cleaveth unto the whore, and which tendeth to death, but also is grievous and against the fathers heart and will, expresseth & manifesteth his mind and will unto his dearly beloved sonne, in this manner; O my tender and deare sonne, for as much as thou art my son, and hath issued out of my bowels, my will and mind is, that thou shouldest be well and stated in good, that is, that thou shouldest stand and live in my will, as becomes the son of such a loving father, and the standing and living in my will is • hy only best outward welbeing and chiefest good; now my will and mind is, that thou be imployed and exercised, in and about the affaires of my will and mind, and they shal not
bee grievious or burthen some unto thee, for I shall direct and lead thy hand, in every thing which I require of thee, and abstain from the whorehouse which my soul abhoreth, there is nothing which is against my will and mind but whoredom, therfore if thou wouldest walke worthy of my love towards thee, if thou wouldest be well, and stated in good; doe not prostitute thy body to an whore, by the infection & contagion of whose filthy disease, thou may be in great danger of (if not lose) thy health of body and life, and ingulfe thy selfe in the element and pit of contrariety to my will, mind, and pleasure.

Thus I tender my will and mind unto thee, and as the man of God Moses said unto the antient people, so say I unto thee, I call Heaven & earth to record this day against thee, that I have set before thee life and death, Deut. 30.19. And I my selfe
will be surety for thy good and welbeing and life in every thing that I require of thee, if so be thou wilt resigne and give up thy selfe to my will and mind, otherwise, neither will I, (nor is it fitting for me to be) bound surety for thy good, health, and life. Now the son although he heare this his fathers divine, and fatherly counsell, yet through the lust of the flesh, and love to please his own humours, he goeth out contra
• y to his fathers mind and will, in unto the who • e, with the young man void of understanding, and behold this whore prevailes with him, and hee committing fornication with her, catcheth, and is so miserably infected with that contagious, and filthy disease, that he loseth the right use of every member of his body, his eyes are dimme, his hands, armes, body, feet, and legges are all festered, & becommeth impotent to
every function, and here is he lying, in this his miserable and wretched condition, to the griefe and displeasure of his loving Father.

Now, if any person or persons, should come and lay the cause of the sonnes misery upon the father, they would be grosly in the wrong, and in unjust judgement; for these th • ee things in the father, namely, Love, forbidding of the evil, grief and displeasure, doe vindicate the pious loving father, from all such aspertions of men, yea, he commeth to the son whilst he is in this woful plight, and expresseth himself in this maner. O my sonne! What hast thou done? where art thou? hast thou endevoured to kill thy selfe, by rejecting my lovely mind and will, and running into that horrid & detestable life, destroying whordom, which I so carefully in my love forbad thee of? O how am I grieved for thee my son?
notwithstanding although thou hast left off to be my sonne, yet I remain thy loving Father.
Wilt thou be made whole? I can cure thee sufficiently and truly.

And here am I as ready and willing to cure thy misery, as I was carefull to forbid thee to run into it, and as I promised my selfe to be surety for thy good and welbeing, if thou hadest remained in my mind and will, so now I promise my selfe to be security for thy recovery and health, if thou, as a subjected patient wilt resigne and give up thy selfe to my will and minde, in thy cure.

And my mind and will is that I shall give, & thou shalt receive these two things; the first is a corrasive which must eate out, and consume all the putrifaction, and invenumed humors of thy infected flesh, and this corrasive in regard of thy vehement disease, may, yea, will seem at
the first more bitter and painfull to thee, then the disease it selfe. But notwithstanding, thou must by an absolute necessity have this same in the fi • st place, otherwise it is impossible for thee to recover health and enjoy life.
The second is, a comfortable pleasant cordiall of a healthfull nature, which must by its vertue give vigor and strength, to the restoring of thee into thy well-being and confi • med estate.
Now the son must be considered two wayes, first, either he su • ject • th himself to the health-giving Father physitian, or else hee rejecteth his fathers offer and his owne recovery.
If in obeying his Fathers will and mind he subject and resigne himselfe up into the hands of the saving father, then he expresseth himselfe after this manner.

O Father I have sinned against heaven,
and before thee, and the sin is more bitter unto my soule, then thy corrasive is or wil be unto my body, therfore welcome corrasive, into thy hands O father, I commit my self to be dealt withall according to thy will and mind, be the corrasive how it will!

And O what unspeakable and fatherly inward bowels and delight is there in the father here, to see the lost son in the way of finding! there are not only hopes, but certainty here, through the goodnesse of all good, that this sick patient shal both stand in his recovered health, and in the will and mind of his owne father againe.
But if in rejecting and disobeying his fathers will and mind here, hee will not submit and resigne himselfe up into the hands of h • s saving father, then he expresseth himselfe after this manner.

Father, I do greatly desire to be recovered, although I be not in great fear of my life, but if that corrasive which you speak of be more bitter and painfull to mee then my disease it self, I had rather be as I am, yet this I wil do, if you wil be pleased to heale me by the comfortable pleasant Cordiall, I wil commit my selfe into your hands, but as for the sharpe and painfull corrasive, I will not meddle with it.
Here is the father no lesse grieved and offended for the sons rejecting, resisting, and refusing his cure, then his running into the disease.
And this disease doth more and more tend to the debility and death of this selfe willed and froward patient, concerning whom, commeth these three questions, briefly to be propounded and answered.
1. The first is, what is the greatest outward misery of this infected person?

Ans. The want of good, that is, not to stand in his fathers will and mind, nor to enjoy sound health and true use of members, senses, and reason, and the having of evil, that is, to stand in his owne will and mind, and to enjoy, or rather to be insorrowed and dye into every evill that is contrary to good.
2. The second is, who is the cause of this evill, misery, and death of this infected person, whether the father or the son himselfe.
Ans. The sonne himselfe, by his owne selfe-will and mind:
3. The third is, whether the father be not as ready to give health to this infected dyin •… person, as he was willing t •… forbid the evill of his infection?
Ans. Certainely he is: And the same is to be said concerning God & creature man, as God hath manifested himselfe clearely in the Scriptures, in which these three things.

Namely, Love, forbidding of sinne, and (so to speake of God, and hee speaks so of himselfe in the Scripture) griefe, (not only for the infectious sin of the creature, but also for the creatures rejecting and slighting such great salvation, as hee offereth to restore it,) doe most evidently and most sweetly shine.

Now, it may be, some will have objections concerning Pharaoh, Esau,
•… nd the like, that God did raise up •… he one, that his power, might be
shewed forth upon him, and that he hardned his heart, and hated the other, that the purpose of God according to election might stand.

To which, and all such questions is answered two wayes, first, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, blessed is the man that endureth temptation, for when he is tryed he shall receive the Crowne of life, which the Lord hath promised to them that love him; let no man say when he is tempted, I am tempted of God, for God cannot be tempted with evill, neither tempteth he any man, but every man is tempted when he is drawne a way of his owne lusts and inticed, then when lust hath conceived, it bringeth forth sinne, and sinne when it is finished bringeth forth death, Iames. 1.12.13, 14, 15.

Secondly, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Behold all
soules are mine, as the soul of the father, so also the soule of the son is mine, the soule that sinneth, that is, the soule that not only runneth into destructive sinne, but also rejecteth the remedy, or the soule which is not baptised with a man in Christ, into a living acting God, and a dead passive creature, which is the substance and end of this treatise, it shall die Ezek. 18.4. And again, he that hath the Sonne hath life, and he that hath not the Sonne hath not life. these things have J written unto you, that beleeve on the name of the Sonne of God, that you might know that ye have Eternall life, and that yee may beleev • on the name of the Sonne of God, 1 Joh. 5.12, 13. And this is the life and light of a man in Christ, concerning this point, which man in Christ, is like unto the Sonne, who becommeth a willing patient to his father, according to the divine truth of that scripture,
he that beleeveth in me, that is, he that doth not reject his cure, and his cure is to be baptised into a living active God, and a dead passive creature, though he were dead, yet shall he live. Iohn, 11.25. all others are like unto the sonne, which wilfully, and obstinately rejecteth his cure, according to the divine truth of that scripture, for God sent not his Sonne into the world, to condemn the world, but that the world through him might be saved, he that beleeveth on him, is not condemned, but he that beleeves not is condemned already, because he hath not beleeved, (that it, because he will not come to Christ, that he may have life, and be baptised in a living active God, and a dead passive creature) in the name of the only begotten, sonne of God. Iohn. 3.17, 18. And againe, the father loveth the sonne, and hath given all things into his hand, he that beleeveth one the Sonne, hath everlasting
life, and he that beleeveth not the Sonne, shall not see life, but the wrath of God abideth one him. Ioh. 3.35, 36. therefore, O earth, earth, earth, heare the word of the Lord. Ieremy. 22.29. Cast away from you al your transgressions, whereby you have transgressed, and make you a new heart, and a new spirit, for why will you dye O house of Israel? for I have no pleasure in the death of him that dyeth saith the Lord God, wherefore turne your selves, and live yee, Ezek. 18.31, 32.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. That a man in Christ, through Christ, doth feele, know and see in himselfe, in some measure, a spirituall Resurrection, which is the true earnest of an exceeding weight of glory unspeakable, and beleeveth the same of all men in Christ. Againe, he doth feele, know, and see in himselfe; that how little a spirituall resurrection is in himself; so little the exceeding weight of glory shall be through all eternity, unlesse it be prevented, and beleeveth the same of all men who are in themselves.
div.p:
THE rationall creature man, i •… to be considered in a two fold condition first, in his bodily essentiall
being. Secondly, in his spirituall essentiall being.

In his bodily essentiall being, observe these two things, first, he is very good: because he is made by God, not by himselfe, for whatsoever God maketh or doth, is very Good, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, And God saw every thing that he had made, and behold it was very Good, Gen. 1.31.

Therefore man in his bodily essentiall being, is a comely good and beautifull creature. Secondly, for as much as he is a bodily essentiall being, made by the Eternall Creator and God of nature, it is imposible that he shall become an abso
•… ute nothing, or non-being, he may •… ndeed be changed, that is, his body may, yea shall goe to its first matter, of which it was made, but annihila
•… ed it cannot be, according to the •… ivine truth of that Scripture, J
know that whatsoever God doth, it shall bee for ever, nothing can be put to it, nor any thing taken from it, and God doth it, that men should feare before him. That which hath beene, it now, and that which is to be, hath already beene, and God requireth that which is past, Eccl. 3.14, 15.

Therefore this bodily essentiall good being, although changed and reduced to its originall matter, doth stand in the all-knowledge and sight of its creator through all eternity, either as it hath beene the Temple of his owne Holy Spirit and life, or hath through violence and injury, been made the Temple of the devill, sinne, and death, by the will of man.

In his spirituall being, observe likewise the same two things, and moreover observe this especially, A man is either A new creature in Christ, or else he is an old man in
Adam; according to the divine truth of these Scriptures, he that is in Christ is a new creature. 2. Cor. 5 17. And againe, for as in Adam all dye, even so in Christ shal al be made alive 1 cor. 15.22.

If he be in Christ, & Christ in him, then he will dye to his owne will, devill, sin, and death, and rise again to the same mind which was also in Christ, that is, to God. holinesse, & everlasting life. If he be in the oldman, and Adam; then hee will dye to the mind, which was in Christ, that is, to God holinesse and everlasting life, and rise againe to his owne will, devill, sin, and death.

Now as the bodily essence changed, and reduced to its first matter, standeth in the all-knowledge and fight of its creator through all eternity, either as it hath been the Temple of his owne Holy Spirit and life, or hath through violence and inju • y beene made the Temple of the devill,
sin, and death, by the will of man; even so the spiritual essence, after dissolution standeth in the all-knowledge & sight of its Creator, th • ough all eternity, either as it hath beene the vicegerent and deputy of his holy Spirit, and life in the body, or the Vicegerent and deputy of the divill, finne, and death, by the will of the creature in the body.

And here is to be observed, in a-divine pondering, that as the two-fold nature of a mā in Christ, namely his bodily and spirituall being, that is, his body and his soule, doth stand in the operative will vertue, all knowledge and sight of their Creator in the time of this momentany •… fe, the one, as the Temple, the other as the vicegerent, of his owne Holy Spirit and life, they both doe and shal arise unto that exceeding weight of glory, through all eternity, which no mortal creature can expresse. According
to the divine truth of that Scripture, Eye hath not seene, nor eare heard, neither have entred into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love him, but God hath revealed them unto us, by his Spirit: for the Spirit searcheth all things, yea the deepe things of God. 1 Cor. 2.9, 10.

Againe, as the twofold nature of a man in Adam, namely, his bodily and spirituall being, that is his body and his soule, doth stand in the alknowledge; and sight of their Creator, in the time of this momentary life, the one as the temple, the other as the vicegerent, of selfe-will devill and sinne, they neither do, nor can arise, unto that exceeding weight of glory, through all eternity, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, but the naturall man, receiveth not the things of the Spirit of God, for they are foolishness unto him, neither
can he know them, because they are spiritually discerned, 1 Cor. 12.14.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. That a man in Christ diligently observeth the Lords day, although his whole life be and must be led and stated in Sabbath, and beleeveth the same of all men in Christ.
div.p:
IT is with a man in Christ and the Lords day in the spirituall talent life, as it is with rich merchants, and such like men in mammon and publique Fairs in the earthly talent life: as into an incorporation, where there is popularity & traffique, there are certaine dayes of the yeare, appoynted, and called Fayres, in and to which, traffiquers and tradesmen do bring and expose their wares, and outward commodities, to be sold to the advancement of their outward estates, and are very exact and diligent
that neither theeves steale any thing from them; nor cozners give them false money, but observeth suspected persons by their eyes, and tryeth the gold, and silver of people by their touchstones and weights, and thus are they exercised and imployed in those fayres or publique market dayes. But now if they got no more traffique and gains through the whole space of the yeare, but what they get in these few dayes of the yeare, they were not able to subsist in their so great earthy undertakings, therefore what they doe in the day and time of the Faire, they doe daily, yea, they thinke the day too little and therefore they take part, yea a great part, of the night many times, such insatiable and ardent affection, they have to multiply the earthly talent. So that all their earthy substance, and riches, doe not altogether consist or
depend only in and upon these few dayes o • the Faires, but also in and upon their daily and nightly traffique and diligence,

It is even so with a man in Christ, in his Spirituall talent-life, in the dayes of the weeke and the Lords day, concerning whom in this Point read over againe, and observe the fourth and fift section.

And moreover, observe here in a divine understanding, that a man in Christ beleeveth that that Sabbath mentioned, by the man of God, Moses, saying, remember the Sabbath day to keepe it Holy, &c. Exod. 20.8. doth tipify and signifie that r • st which remaineth to the people • f God, Heb. 4 9 which rest is to be • aptised into a living acting God, • nd a dead passive creature; without whi • h he can neither keepe the Sabbath, nor be a man in Christ, let him observe one day of seaven never
so strictly, and professe christianity never so eminently, and this may be clearly proved, and confirmed by the true testimony of the out-spoken word of GOD, both before and after Moses as in Cain and Abel, the one being a temporary, the other a Sabbaticall worshipper, so in Iacob and Esau, so in the strict pharisee, and Publican and the like.

Therefore whosoever would be as Abel, Iacob, and the justified Publican, whosoever would be stated in the true Sabbath, hee must be baptised with a man in Christ, into a living active God, and a dead passive creature. Otherwise let him do what he will, hee is and willbe as Cain, Esau, and the strict Pharisee, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Hee that is not with mee, is against mee, and hee that gathereth not with me, that is, he that is not baptised in a living active God, & a dead passive creature, scattereth Mat. 12.30.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. That a man in Christ doth feel, know, & see in himself, that as he is in Christ, Christ both doth & shall raign upon his earth, that is, the will of the Father in the Son shall in some proportionable measure be done in his earthy body and nature to the subjugating and mortifying thereof, as it shall be done thorow all eternity, in the endlesse spirituall life: and beleeveth the same of all men in Christ.
div.p:
IEHOVAH, God the Lord, having absolute perfect knowledge what man would do, before ever man was created, doth create him, and giveth him a law, that he should feed upon the tree of life, which was, and is God himselfe: and abstain from the tree of knowledge
of good and evill, which was, and is man himselfe; But now man Adam, runneth after the forbidden Tree, which poysoneth him, and causeth death to have power against him, and so he is miserable, poysoned, and mortall, as was also said in the fifteenth Section.

And Jehovah God, the Lord of mercy, in his eternall love, doth find out a way of mercy, health and life, to compassionate his misery, to expell his poyson, and to change his mortallity into immortallity, and everlasting life; according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Verily, Verily I say unto you, he that believeth on me, hath everlasting life Ioh. 6.47. And this lovely way, is the Way, Truth, and Life, even the Lord Christ, the Rock of everlasting life; according to this same Scripture, Whom the Father hath • egotten as himselfe, from all eternity, to
be the salvation and restauration of all that will, and shall by grace, become men in Christ, and this Christ being the very essence of Heaven, and fulnesse thereof, and the consistence of the earth, for by him all things consist, Coloss. 1.17. As the re-standing of all that falleth, and this is only sinfull falling man.

And as that everlasting light which shineth in, & upon the darknes of sinfull falling man, hath alwayes shined in and upon the man, as the Sun hath alwayes shined upon the Creation; But such hath bin, and such is the darkenesse, that it hath not, nor yet doth, comprehend the light, which shineth in the darkenesse, and the darknesse comprehendeth it not, as the man in Christ, John sayth, Joh. 1.5. And this glorious spirituall heavenly light, is the City set on a Hill, and cannot be hid; it is the bright shining
Candle, which is not put under a Bushell, but is set on a Candlesticke, to give light to all that are in the house; The Sun and Moone are as sparkling visible figures, of this infinite everlasting light, who giveth their splendor to every creature, that is capable to receive it, & offereth it to the poor and base, aswell as to the rich and honourable, aswell to the unjust as to the just, according to the divine truth of that Scripture For he maketh his Sun to rise on the evill and on the Good, & sendeth rain on the just and unjust, Math. 3.45. So that the Day-spring, and great light Christ, is risen and come into the world, but men love darknes rather then light, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, And this is the condemnation that light is come into the world, and men love darkenes rather then light, because their deeds were evill, Joh. 3.19

But now, unto this Lord Chrsst, the true life and light of men, do all the Prophets and apostles, and all other men in Christ, give witnes, and do put to their Seal, that he is a child born to them, a son given unto them, and the government is upon his shoulders and he shall call his name Wonderfull Councellor, the mighty God, the everlasting Father, the Prince of Peace, the increase of his government & Peace shall have no end, Isaiah, 9.6, 7.

And as the man of God Esayas, so also, all the other Prophets, doe in a sweet harmony, breath out, the purity and excellency of this spirituall lovely government, and peaceable Kingdome of this Prince of Peace, in every Soul and body of every man in Christ, in particular, and in them all in generall, wheresoever they be dispersed through the habitable world amongst
men, as Wheat amongst the Tares, as Gold in and amongst Fires, as Sheep amongst Wolves.

And although as they are men, they may within themselves, Joseph like, have a seducing Where to tempt, and a Potiphar to imprison them; and without themselves Shimeies to curse, Hams to mocke, and false Bretheren to murther, and sell them, in a spirituall malignity, and evill eye, and so being considered in the outward man, they hav • trouble both within and withou • themselves, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, In the world yee shall have tribulation, Joh. 16.33. Yet as they are men in Christ, they have Joseph-like times of refreshment which fl • w from the presence o • the Prince of Peace, Christ, who as in his own person, and mysterious exhibiting of himselfe, as the Sunconquering King, by goodnes, patience,
and love, did overcome Devil, Sin and Death: Even so he hath done, doth, and shall doe, in all that hath been, are, and shall bee, men in Christ, and members of his mysticall body, to the abollishing of the Kingdome of Devil, Sin and Death, in his members, and to the magnifying and manifestation of his al-glorious Diadem of Grace, and spirituall Kingdome of glory and preheminence.

But now, as was said before, the carnall worldly mindes of men, having darknes in stead of true light, and being not able to know the glory and excellency of Christ, the Prince of Peace, in his Kingdome, because he is spiritually discerned, as was cited in the Closure of the sixteenth Section, have alwayes in seeing, not seen, and in hearing, not understood, the mystery of the Kingdome of CHRIST, and
therefore it seemes the Pharisees having punctually read over the Prophets, concerning the Kingdome of Christ, which no carnall mind can know, demanded o • Christ, when the Kingdome of God should come; which they by their carnall accute understanding, conceived to come, in an outward humane splendor and earthly glory; after the manner of man, as man he answered them and said, The Kingdome of Heaven commeth not with observation, Luk. 17.20, 21. In the Greek Language it is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, it commeth not with outward shew, neither shall they say, loe here, or loe there, For behold the Kingdome of God is within you, yea the very Disciples themselves in Acts 1.6. asked of him saying, Lord, wilt thou at this time restore again the Kingdome to Jsrael? And he said unto them, it is not for you
to know the times & the seasons, which the Father hath put in his own power, but yee shall receive power after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you, and you shall witnesse unto me, both in Ierusalem, and in all Judea, and in Samaria, and to the utmost parts of the earth; In the Greek language it is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
that is, but you shall receive power of the Holy Ghost, comming upon you, so that if the Pharisees would feele, know, and see, the Kingdome of Christ, they must not thinke to feel, know, and see it in outward shew, after the manner of men, but in an internall spirituallity, and if the Lords People will feel, know, and see, the Kingdome restored again to Jsrael; that is, the exalting of the Kingdome of Christ in the Saints, that is, in men in Christ they must feel, know and see it, in the power of the Holy Spirit &
the power of the holy Spirit, & the power of the holy Spirit in themselves, in an internall spirituallity.

Some it may be will object, and say. If Christs Kingdome, be but a Spirituall Kingdome, this will be much derogatory to Christ, and contradictory to so many places of Scripture, which holds out such a glorious Raign, as Christ must have upon earth, In a visible Monarchicall Kingdome, for a thousand yeares, and the like.

To which in love I answer; To say so, doth argue much of that which doth rather savour of the things that be of men, then the things that be of God, unlesse the Spirit of God and truth, teach the meaning of Scripture.

For is it derogatory to the Sun, that it sendeth forth its light, and heat u • to the earth, and causeth it to be a fruitfull mother of all vegetive,
brute, and rationall creatures, although it selfe be exalted, and distant from the earth, in such a vast and mighty distance? Is it not rather the glory and excellency of that solary created nature, to produce such wonderfull effects, as it doth in such a distance?

If that glorious created nature were upon the earth, amongst the inferiour creatures, then First, this would be derogatory to its glorious and excellent nature, in that its great power and efficacy, should not be manifested, but in-dignifyed and derogated from.

And secondly, the earth and all the Creatures in it, being Corporall and earthly, and not able to endure the Immense light, and heate, would all melt and be consumed, which is against the order & State of the visible creation, in which, as in an Image and visible representation
of the Creator, the invisible things, of him, from the creation of the World, are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made, even his eternall power and Godhead.

Even so is it derogatory to the Creator of the sun, and whole universall nature, that he, being the Almighty Spirit, and Being of all Beings, Who humbleth himselfe, to behold the things that are in Heaven, and in the earth, Psal. 113.6. Should manifest his eternall power and Godhead; by filling the Heaven, earth, and Sea, with his goodnesse in such a manner, as becometh the Al-glorious, and infinite power, and Godhead, and as his creatures, each in their own kind may in some small measure be capable of him, and all of them, and especially the rationall creature, to stand in a holy admiration of his immensity, &
eternity? For who amongst us shall dwell among everlasting burnings? Esay 33.14. Or who shall, or can teach the Lord to have a glorious Raign? Shall poor, vain, witlesse creature-man, think that the Lord God Christ shall be an exalted King after the manner of the Kings of clay upon earth? according to the divine truth of that Scripture, who hath directed the Spirit of the Lord, or being his Councellor, hath taught him? With whom tooke he councell, and who instructed or taught him, in the path of Judgement? And taught him knowledge, and shewed to him the way of understanding?

Behold the Nations are as a drop of a Bucket, and are counted as the small dust of the Ballance; He taketh up the Jsles as a very little thing, and Lebanon is not sufficient to burn, nor the Beasts thereof, for a Burnt Offering.

All Nations before him are as nothing,
and they are counted to him lesse then nothing and vanity; to whom then will you liken God, or what likenesse will you compare him unto? Have yee not known? Have ye not heard? Hath it not been told you from the beginning? Have yee not understood from the foundation of the earth? It is He that sitteth upon the circle of the earth, and the inhabitants thereof are ltke Grassehoppers; That stretcheth out the Heavens as a Curtain, and spreadeth them out, as a Tent to dwell in Esay 40. from 13, to 19. & 21, & 22. ver.

So that the glorious Kingdome of the Lord God Christ is infinitely greater, and more glorious, then poor finite creature-man can desire it to be; For his dominion is an everlasting dominion, and his Kingdome is from genera • ion to generation, as the man of God Daniel, hath it in his 4th Chap. ver. 34.

And here is to be observed in a
heavenly uuderstanding, that the Kingdome of the Lord Christ (if it may be lawfull to say so) is twofold; The one is the Kingdome of grace, and this Kingdome is stated in time; The other, is the Kingdome of glory, and this Kingdome is stated in eternity.

Those that are truly stated in the Kingdome of Grace, do through Christ, love Christ their King and Lord, aswell as they love the Kingdome of glory: And therefore theirs only is the Kingdome of glory; according to the divine truth of that Scripture, And every one that hath forsaken Houses, or bretheren, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or lands, for my names sake, shall receive an hundred fold, and shall inherit everlasting life, Math. 19.29. And those that are truly stated in a living active God, and a dead passive creature, do thorow this State,
which State is the Fathers drawing) love the will of the Father to be done in them, and not their own, as well as they love Christ, and therefore th • y only are in the Kingdome of Grace; according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Not every one that saith Lord, Lord, shall enter into the Kingdome of Heaven, but he that doth the will of my Father which is in Heaven, Math. 7.21. And again, Then said I lo I come, in the Volumne of thy Booke it is written of me, I delight to do thy will, O my God, yea, thy law is within my heart, Psal. 40.7.8.

And now, friendly Reader, having held out the Life and Light of a man in Christ, in judgement and understanding. aswell as in practicall religious performances, comparatively with other men, for thy sake and for thy good, without wearying and burthening of thy
memory any further; Here I shall conclude this little Treatise, committing thee and it, to the grouth and grace of God and truth.

Only let me intreat thus much of thee; Beware how thou readest it; Thou wilt never read it right, unlesse thou understand it, and thou wilt never understand it, unlesse thou be wise in God, and thou wilt never be wise in God, unlesse thou become a fool in thine own eyes; according to the divine truth of that Scripture, Let no man deceive himselfe, if any man among you seemeth to be wise in this World, let him become a fool, that he may be wise: for the wisdome of this world is foolishnes with God, for it is written, He taketh the wise in their own craftines; And again, The Lord knoweth the thoughts of the wise that they are vain, 1. Cor. 3.18, 19.

Therefore in reading this little
Treatise, as also in all thy other busines, thirst after the Wisdome, and Spirit of God, and thou shalt be satisfyed, according to the divine truth of that Scripture, If any of you lack wisdome, let him aske of God that giveth to all men liberally, and upbraideth not, and it shall be given him, but let him aske in faith, nothing wavering, that is, let him be baptised in a living active God, & a dead passive creature, otherwise, he is like a wave of the Sea, driven with the wind, and tossed, for let not that man thinke, that he shall receive any thing of the Lord; a double minded man is unstable in all his wayes, Jam. 1.5.6, 7, 8. And again, Jf yee then being evill, know how to give good gifts unto your children, how much more shall your heavenly Father give the Holy spirit, to them that aske him, that is, who is baptised into a living active God, &
a dead passive Creature.
And this divine baptism, which is the end & scope of this little treatise, and thy chiefest good under the Sun, is here presented unto thee.
This divine baptisme, what is it else, but the Mariage Dinner of the Kings son? And this little Treatise what is it else, but one of the Kings servants, calling thee who are bidden to come?

If thy Farm, or thy merchandize, that is thy selfe, be dearer to thee then this; then Know, that thou art one of those unto whom God and truth saith, The wedding is ready, but thou who wast bidden, art •• t worthy, Mat. 22.8. & here I dare confidently perswade thee of two things, the First is, if thou knewest the gift of God, and what this Kings son is who bids thee come, thou wouldest come, & he would give thee living water, Joh. 4.10.

The second is, if thou wilt not come, that is, if thou wilt not have the life & action of the Lord thy God to live & act in thee, which is his glory, & thy eternal happines, But will live and act, in thy own will, life, and action, although thou seeme never so holy and religious, in the eyes of such as thy selfe, and sit down at the Table, that is, be never so observative and frequent in hearing, speaking reading praying and the like, yet thou art that man, which had not on a Wedding Garment, and being speechlesse in the sight of God and truth was commanded to be bound hand and foot, and taken away, and cast into utter darknes, where there is weeping and gnashing of Teeth, Math. 22.13. which I desire the to be delivered from.

But if thou with Ioseph, who art called to come out of Prison, that is, out of thy selfe, unto good King
Pharaoh, that is, unto Christ and his baptisme, shave thy selfe, change thy rayment, and come, then thou art as Joseph, that is increasing, unto whom Jsrael his blessing belongeth saying, The blessings of thy Father have prevailed above the blessings of my Progenitors, unto the utmost bound of the everlasting Hills, they shall be on the head of Joseph, & on the crown of the head of him that was separate from his bretheren; That is, baptised in a living active God, and a dead passive creature, Gen. 49.26.
And the Spirit & the Bride say come, and let him that heareth say come, and let him that is a thirst come, & whosoever will let him take the water of life freely, Rev. 18.17. Amen.
